story: Created with Sketch.Russian president expresses hope leaders will discuss 'bilateral relations and important matters'Click to followThe Independent OnlineVladimir Putin ready to meet Kim Jong-un to discuss 'urgent issues', says North Korean state mediaThe Russian&nbsppresident congratulated Mr Kim in a telegram to mark&nbspNorth Korea’s national liberation day,&nbspwhich commemorates&nbspthe end of the Second World War and the north’s liberation from Japanese colonial rule, the KCNA news agency reported.“I affirm that I am ready to meet you at an early date to discuss urgent issues of bilateral relations and important matters of the region,” Mr Putin said in the message, without offering a specific date.North and South Korean leaders announce Pyongyang summitNorth Korea hits out at US sanctions and demands to denucleariseNorth Korea has not stopped nuclear weapons programme, UN saysTrump thanks Kim Jong-un for ‘nice letter’ and ‘kind actions’He also expressed hope&nbspthe countries would “continue to develop cooperation for mutual benefits including the realisation of the tripartite project” which would also involve South Korea.Speaking to journalists on Wednesday, the Kremlin’s spokesman, Dmitry&nbspPeskov, confirmed Mr Putin had sent the telegram in which he “stressed his desire and readiness to establish a dialogue,” Channel NewsAsia reported.In June, Mr Putin invited Mr Kim and South Korea’s president, Moon Jae-in, to an economic forum due to take place in Vlaostok next month. It is unclear whether the North Korean leader responded.When Mr Peskov was asked whether the two leaders could meet in Vlaostok, he said the economic forum is&nbsp”open for all the leaders of the region” but said Moscow has “so far” received no confirmation&nbspfrom Pyongyang to indicate Mr Kim&nbspwill attend.Mr Kim also sent a message to Mr Putin, KCNA reported, noting the “valuable tradition” as they “struggled shoulder to shoulder against the common enemy in the arduous anti-Japanese war”, which it said provided the “strong roots” for their diplomatic relations.It was unclear if the message came before or after Mr Putin’s invitation.It comes as North Korea marked its liberation from Japanese rule&nbspwith relatively low-key celebrations.A group of war veterans from the former Soviet Union participated and thousands of people cheered their football team to victory over a South Korean squad in the opening match of an under-15 youth tournament in Pyongyang, which featured players from several countries.People also streamed to statues of the country’s leaders or other monuments to observe the anniversary, as is customary.Escape from North KoreaA hat belonging to Jeong Min-woo in Seoul. Min-woo is from Hyesan, on the border with China. He was a commissioned officer in the Korean People's Army, and left in his uniform. South Korean intelligence confiscated it, but he persuaded his North Korean military contacts to send him a new one.Jeong Min-woo, 29, poses for a photograph in SeoulKang, 28, who wanted to be identified only by her surname, poses for a photograph in Seoul. The parents of Kang sent out a coat across the Chinese border after she reached the South in 2010. I didn't ask my mother to send me this coat, said Kang. But she knew I feel the cold easily and sent it to me. She sent some honey too, but it went missing on the way. The coat is made of dog fur. I don't know what kind of dog. In 2010, it cost about 700,000 North Korean won ($88 at the unofficial rate). It was really expensive. A North Korean friend went to China to pick it up for me. I liked this coat when I got it. I thought my mother must've spent quite a lot of money on it.  The dog fur coat belonging to Kang, My father was a party officer. Our family had a car and we lived in a special apartment. Ordinary people couldn't afford to wear this kind of coat, not even soldiers. Commissioned officers could afford them. Border guards would wear them. It wasn't easy to buy this kind of coat, but as time went on, fake ones began to appear. The state often clamped down on this item. It's technically military supplies so the state monitored people who altered the design of the coat. I know just from looking at this coat that it's a counterfeit one, not the official version. The counterfeit ones look quite different from the original ones. Military officials preferred the fakes to the original because the design looked much better. The children of rich families would wear them. I look too chubby in this, so don't wear it here. I thought I could probably wear it if I altered it.Lee Oui-ryuk is from Onsong, near the border with China. He defected in 2010, and brought his ID card with him. I brought my ID with me when I left North Korea. Juche 95.11.7 (the date in the North Korean calendar, which equates to Nov. 7, 2006) is the date I was issued with my ID. It says here my blood type is A, but I'm actually an O. For the 23 years I lived in North Korea, I thought my blood type was A. They wrote down my blood type without even doing a test. They just wrote whatever they wanted to. I was caught trying to defect to South Korea around Kim Jong Il's birthday. They strengthen border security just before and after that date.The bottom of the lamp is dark, as the saying goes, and I thought I'd be able to cross right under their noses. The soldiers shot at me as I tried to run away from the Tumen River. I managed to get away and hid, but someone reported me and I was caught. That's when I was taken to the bowibu (North Korean secret police) for three months of interrogation. The state ruled that I had tried to defect to South Korea, and I was sent to a camp for political prisoners. I escaped when they were transferring me to the camp. I hid and managed to make it to my big sister's house - that's when I grabbed these photos. I couldn't go home easily, so decided I had to hide in the mountains or somewhere remote. I needed my ID to move around without getting caught. and I took these 12 photos with me in case I wanted to look back and reminisce. I wrote on the back of them so as not to forget.Ji Sung-ho, 35, from Hoeryong, near the border with China. He left North Korea in 2006 with a pair of wooden crutches. I lived as a child beggar in North Korea. I was stealing coals from a train when I fell off and lost my leg and my hand. I had to bring the crutches with me. If I didn't have them, I wouldn't have made it here. The state doesn't help you in North Korea, and people who need crutches make their own. Mine are therefore not factory-made, so they're not perfect and break easily. I had several pairs of crutches but they all broke, and this was the last pair. I used these crutches for 10 years, until I was 25, when I arrived in South Korea. I would steal coal from moving trains and fall off, destroying my crutches. Or I would get beaten up by the police and they'd take and then break my crutches. When they broke, I would make new ones. When I had new ones, I could go back outside.When I first arrived in South Korea I thought about throwing them out. South Korea's intelligence agency gave me a prosthetic leg. My friends said I should throw the crutches out and not think about North Korea. They said I should show Kim Jong Il I was living a new life in South Korea and throw out everything I had from the North. Some asked if I got upset when I saw my crutches. But I couldn't just throw them out. To make my crutches, my friends had given me some wood that they had bought, and someone I knew in North Korea who had carpentry skills had made them. It was my father who added the final touches. There is a lot of love from my North Korean friends and family in these crutches. So I didn't throw them out. The South Korean government gave me some new crutches because the wood from my North Korean ones is hard and painful. But I still keep them, so as not to forget those memories. Kim Ryen Hui, 48, is from Pyongyang. She says she never wanted to defect. In 2011, she says, a broker helped her go to China for treatment on her liver. But the broker tricked her, she said, and she ended up in South Korea. She is campaigning to return, which Seoul says would be against the law. I miss my parents even more than I miss my daughter. They're everything to me. For the first few years, I couldn't even breathe properly when I thought of them. My little brother lives with them in Pyongyang now. My mother can't see out of one eye. The thing I fear the most is finding out they've passed away before I have the chance to go back. My daughter and I have been writing letters and sending photos to each other. That's why she was doing taekwondo - to get involved in anti-South espionage. So I was really surprised to hear she became a chef. In a video of her I received, she explained why. She said that after I had left, she moved in with her father in Pyongyang and had been cooking for him. She said she decided to become a chef so she could fulfill my role at home. I was sad when I heard that.Lee Min-bok, 60, was a researcher at North Korea's Academy of Agricultural Science. He first tried to defect, unsuccessfully, in 1990. He eventually left North Korea in June 1991 and came to South Korea in 1995. His family sent him these diaries. I have a bit of an academic side. According to Kim Il Sung's teachings, people are supposed to keep diaries. Everyone in North Korea should strictly follow Kim Il Sung's teachings, so I did as I was supposed to and kept a diary. Even though Kim Il Sung is a villain here, in North Korea he's above everything. We learned that he studied well and gave our lives purpose. I lived according to those teachings. I wrote these out of loyalty to the Leader. That was our ideology, and I lived my life in strict adherence to it. No one could think differently.I got hold of these diaries 10 years after I arrived in South Korea. I had been sending money to my family in the North and they sent them to me. I didn't write any complaints in diaries. I would've been in big trouble if I did. My diaries are a record of my history in North Korea. I am thinking about turning these diaries into a book. I'd like to publish a book about how to change North Koreans' thinking when unification happens. These diaries show how North Koreans think and how their minds are constructed. People need to make these into a textbook, because they need proof. Talking is not as effective.Song Byeok was a propaganda artist. His father drowned trying to cross the Tumen river, in 2000. When the artist finally left North Korea in 2001, he brought photos of his family with him. We left that August to find food, Byeok recalled, describing the first attempt. We were from a town further inland, and we weren't sure where the river was high and where it was low. I didn't know at the time but the river was swollen because of the rainy season. I thought we had to cross it anyway. All I could think about was getting to China to buy food. I took off my clothes and tied them into a rope to strap us together. I told my father not to let go. I rushed up to the (North Korean) border guards and asked them to save him but they just said why did I come out, why didn't I die too. They handcuffed me and took me away. It was Aug. 28. story: Created with Sketch.Demonstrators carry toys owned by&nbsptheir sons and daughters – highlighting the ages of some of those who have been arrestedClick to followThe Independent OnlineYekaterina Milanovskaya was one of those who attended the rallyHundreds of Russians braved lightning storms and potential arrest to take part in an unsanctioned rally protesting the controversial imprisonment of a group of young anarchists. &nbspThe anarchists, who called themselves “the New Greatness”, are alleged to have plotted to violently overthrow the Russian system. But details of the case are&nbspmurky.From meetings in McDonald’s, the group is alleged to have agreed on a revolution via social media and leafleting. Police arrested 10&nbspmembers of the group in March.The rally in Moscow’s central New Pushkin Square&nbspstyled itself as a “mothers’ march”. Huddled under umbrellas, the mostly female protesters carried toys of their sons and daughters. Some carried unicorns in&nbspreference to the “My Little Pony” that&nbspAnna Pavlikova,&nbspthe youngest of the imprisoned anarchists, loved to collect. But with political messages banned, it also&nbspwas the protesters’ way of identifying each other and avoiding arrest.&nbsp“This is my son’s little tiger,” said Yekaterina Milanovskaya, 40, holding up an orange soft toy. “We bought it for him on his first new year. He’s 14 now,&nbspall brave and happy. But it doesn’t take much to imagine him getting involved in&nbspa little mutiny somewhere, and getting&nbsparrested. That’s what authorities are doing. They want&nbspto scare people like me, to keep the&nbspkids from protesting.”&nbsp&nbspJournalist Anna Narinskaya, one of the organisers of the&nbspprotest, told The Independent that the rally’s aims&nbspwere two-fold: to bring attention to the “injustice” of the case and to demand the release the two youngest members of the group, who are&nbspsuffering from serious ill-health. Anna Pavlikova, now 18,&nbsphas lost part of her hearing, and Maria Dubovik,19, has a tumour. Both also&nbspsuffer from panic attacks.&nbsp“We are against the whole absurd case, but even on the government’s own terms as they present to us, the treatment of these girls goes beyond the humane,” she said. “This protest has been organised by mothers for mothers. We understand that all of our children are at risk. Any of them could be tricked into something like this.”&nbspThe existence of the opposition movement seems to have come as a surprise to everyone except Russia’s law enforcement.&nbspThe group is alleged to have undertaken weapons training ahead of a revolutionary campaign. But the main sources of the evidence are security officers who infiltrated their network. At least one played a significant role in directing the group’s activities.&nbspAccording to supporters and&nbsplawyers acting for the youngsters, the actions of security services amounted to an illegal act of provocation. They say the security agents were instrumental in pushing the group to greater militancy.&nbsp“They invented the revolution themselves and then found people to fill the gaps,” says organiser Ms Narinskaya.&nbspAhead of the rally, police warned that participation&nbsprisked fines and arrests. As per Russia’s controversial protest laws, any political gathering requires permission from local authorities. Opposition actions are rarely granted permission without long delays, or locations away from the city centre. As a result, organisers&nbspdid not even try to get permission. story: Created with Sketch.Crossbencher Fraser Anning widely condemned for his isive remarksClick to followIndy PoliticsAn Australian politician has provoked outrage after using the term “final solution” in an incendiary&nbspspeech about immigration, in which he called for a plebiscite asking voters whether they want to stop&nbspMuslims and those “from the third world” from entering the country.Queensland senator Fraser Anning’s provocative maiden speech called for an immigration program that favours “European Christian” values, claiming it would protect Australia from potential terror attacks.We as a nation are entitled to insist that those who are allowed to come here predominantly reflect the historic European-Christian composition of Australian society, the Katter’s Australian Party upper house MP said.Trump isn’t the only one whose immigration policy is doomed to failLaura Ingraham defends her immigration comments, disavows David DukeIf Trump got his way, Melania's parents would be illegal immigrantsMr Anning, who replaced Malcolm Roberts in the Senate back in June, called for “a plebiscite to allow the Australian people to decide whether they want wholesale non-English speaking immigrants from the third world, and particularly whether they want any Muslims”.“The majority of Muslims in Australia of working age do not work and exist on welfare. Muslims in New South Wales and Victoria are three times more likely than other groups to be convicted of crimes, he claimed.&nbsp“We have black African Muslim gangs terrorising Melbourne, we have Isis-sympathising Muslims trying to go overseas to try and fight for Isis and while all Muslims are not terrorists, certainly all terrorists these days are Muslims.“So why would anyone want to bring more of them here?”He went on to state&nbspthat&nbspmigrates should learn the English language and embrace Australian values.“Ethnocultural ersity ... has been allowed to rise to dangerous levels in many suburbs, he said.In direct response, self-segregation, including white flight from poorer inner-urban areas, has become the norm.World news in picturesIndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi greets schoolchildren after his speech as part of India's 72nd Independence Day celebrations which marks the 71st anniversary of the end of British colonial rule, at the Red Fort in New DelhiA large section of the Morandi viaduct upon which the A10 motorway runs collapsed in Genoa, Italy. story: Patrick O&rsquoFlynn said Downing Street is in the final stages of a plan which would effectively &ldquorebadge the existing arrangement after a few minor changes and would prioritise migrants from EU countries.The Ukip MEP, who represents the East of England, said the new system &ldquokeeps a virtually open door to any with job offers.His shock claim comes as a fresh legal challenge to stop Brexit has been launched by a group of British expats living on the continent.The legal bid by the UK in EU Challenge group says the conduct of pro-Leave organisations in the run-up to the 2016 referendum should nullify the result of the historic vote.Leave.EU was recently fined &pound70,000 following an investigation by the Electoral Commission for offences committed under electoral law.The UK in EU Challenge group will argue the electoral offences committed by Leave.EU should void the of both the result of the referendum and the notification to leave the EU under Article 50.                Trade expert predicts second Brexit referendum by end of 2018                Rees-Mogg spearheads new Brexit plan with 'POSITIVE' futureIn a statement, the group said: The rights of the estimated one to two million British nationals who live, work or have other interests in other member states are profoundly affected by Brexit.In the event of a 'no deal', they will lose their current legal status.Even if there is a deal, they risk losing their right to live and work in other EU countries.Sue Wilson, one of the claimants who lives in Spain, said: We hope to demonstrate that you can't win by cheating.Brexit news: The latest legal challenge is based on an investigation by the Electoral Commission (Image: )If there is another referendum, there mustn't be a repeat of the illegal activity witnessed last time round.We have not taken back control - we have been put in the hands of those that care more about their careers and political party than their country.The UK deserves better, we deserve better, and we won't stop fighting until we succeed.The latest challenge will only be heard if a High Court judge at a future date grants permission for a hearing.Follow Express's live blog for all the latest Brexit news:&nbsp                EU drugs watchdog blames Brexit for delays to update info guideline                African banana farms fear being WIPED OUT by Brexit10pm: Nearly half of Scots support second Brexit referendum, new poll revealsA vote on the final Brexit deal has the backing of 48 percent of people in Scotland, according to new polling.The YouGov poll, which was commissioned by the People's Vote campaign, a group calling for a public vote following the Brexit negotiations, found 31 percent were against a second referendum.Just 12 percent of Scots surveyed said they believe Britain will get a good Brexit deal.The poll quizzed 2,013 people between August 8 and August 14 and found support for remaining in the EU had increased since the 2016 referendum.Two-thirds (66 percent) said they wanted to remain while 34 percent were pro-Brexit, when the don't knows were removed.In the 2016 referendum voters in Scotland were split 62 percent to 38 percent for remain over leave.New polling suggests opinion in Scotland has shifted closer towards a majority a second Brexit vote (Image:  IMAGES)9.20pm: Gordon Brown claims more than a MILLION Brexit voters have changed their mindIn his most outspoken Brexit intervention yet, the former Prime Minister said polling shows Labour voters who had previously backed leaving the EU are now in favour of staying in.Citing a recent poll by campaign group Hope Not Hate, Mr Brown said the number of people who have changed their mind since the 2016 referendum now numbered more than one million.Speaking at the Edinburgh International Book Festival, the Labour politician said none of the proposed Brexit deals would deliver what was promised to voters.He said: &ldquoIronically, Leavers and Remainers now do have one thing in common - both are increasingly losing hope for a better future for Britain.Remain voters are despondent, fearing that we have moved from a soft Brexit to a hard Brexit to a no-deal Brexit.&ldquoBut leave voters believe that none of the Brexit options- a Norway-style deal, a Swiss-style deal or the Canadian option - can deliver what they were promised and now feel Andrew Bridgen predicted EU support in Ireland will plummet after Brexit (Image: EXPRESS.CO.UK)6.15pm: Brussels will NOT allow May to deal directly with EU leaders - reportEuropean officials have reportedly rejected claims Theresa May could bypass the Commission on Brexit and begin direct talks with EU leaders.Heads and state and government from across the bloc are due to meet next month at a summit in Salzburg, Austria.The event is due to be dominated by the subject of migration, though European Council president Donald Tusk could allow Brexit to be added to the agenda.But a senior diplomatic source has told the  the EU will not suddenly change its Brexit strategy and allow Mrs May to deal directly with EU leaders.The source said: &ldquoThat is completely ridiculous, that is complete overspin of Salzburg.&ldquoIt would mean that we would ditch our negotiating approach of the last two years and discuss at 28 instead of 27 to one, and I don&rsquot see why this would happen.                British MEP TRASHES May over 'CAPITULATION' to EU                Dragons' Den star claims it is DEMOCRATIC to have second Brexit vote Mrs May will reportedly be stopped from dealing directly with EU leaders to secure a Brexit deal (Image:  IMAGES)4.30pm: Continued supply of more than 100 medicines in doubt after Brexit, EU drug watchdog warnsThe European Medicines Agency (EMA) has expressed &ldquoserious doubts over whether 108 medications will be available in the EU after Brexit.The EMA warned the drugs could be banned from being sold in the bloc because their manufacturers have not job offers.&nbsp&nbspMEP Patrick O'Flynn claimed the Government is reaching a deal with the EU (Image: TWITTER)12.55pm update: Angela Merkel SCOLDED by EU budged commissioner&nbspEU budget commissioner Gunther Oettinger urged Germany to step up its financial efforts and help the bloc cover the &pound10bn financial blackhole the UK withdrawal will cause.&nbspMr Oettinger reminded the German Chancellor she had previously&nbsppledged to &ldquostrengthen the EU financially, so that they can perform their duties better.&nbspBut, he said, Berlin seems to contradict itself, as the German finance minister had also stated that&nbspeven a one percent commitment would lead to Germany shouldering the majority of the burden left by Brexit.He said:&nbsp&ldquoWhen finance minister Olaf Scholz speaks of a volume of the budget of 1.0 percent of European economic output, then I see that as a first offer.&nbsp&ldquoBut it is also clear: Scholz&rsquos offer is in contradiction to the forthcoming discussions on the EU budget.Brexit news: Gunther Oettinger scolded Germany and urged it to contribute more into the EU budget (Image: )12pm update: Pro-EU campaigners seek advice to REVERSE Brexit&nbspPro-EU campaigners seeking to establish&nbsplegally whether Britain alone could stop the Brexit process have appealed to Scotland's top court earlier today in a bid to reverse the decision taken on June.&nbspThe campaigners want judges to ask the European Court of Justice (ECJ) to clarify if the country could choose to remain in the EU without the permission of the EU27.That would require Britain's parliament to first vote down the final Brexit deal.Two months ago, judges from the Edinburgh Court of Session&nbspsaid they could not refer the matter to the ECJ because Britain had not decided to overturn Brexit, and the case was therefore hypothetical.&nbspChris Grayling has urged a 're-doubling' of efforts to strike a Brexit deal (Image: )10.55am update: Chris Grayling urges to RE-DOUBLE the efforts to strike a Brexit deal&nbspBrexit-backing Transport Secretary Chris Grayling has urged British negotiators to keep working hard to find an agreement with Brussels.&nbspHe said: None of us want no deal, none of us are working towards that, I think it would be damaging for both this country and the EU.We've got to re-double our efforts to make sure we reach the right agreement this autumn and that's why Theresa May has brought forward the Chequers proposals.They are not easy to sell in this country as we know, they are difficult for Brexiteers to accept.But Mr&nbspGrayling argued that a deal should bear in mind the will of the people who voted Brexit to regain control of their country.He added:&nbspMy view, having thought about this very carefully, is that they do offer us a way to reach an agreement with the EU.I didn't campaign to leave the EU in order to have a different specification of motorcar in France to in the UK, so I can accept having alignment on the technical specifications of manufactured goods, if that is the price we need to pay in order to have a sensible relationship for the future.&nbspBrexit news: Jeremy Hunt has met his counterparts in Finland, Latvia, Denmark and the Netherlands (Image: )10.45am update: Jeremy Hunt warned about the &ldquosignificant short-term impact of a no-deal BrexitThe Brexit Secretary has warned about the impact he believes a no-deal Brexit will have on the markets.Speaking from Lithuania, Jeremy Hunt said: Well, of course, there will be significant short-term impact, but I think in these situations the British economy would find a way to get through it and, indeed, we would find a way ultimately to thrive and be successful.His latest comment comes after he urged title: brexit news second eu referendum survey alistair burt andrew bridgen
story: Tory frontbencher Alistair Burt, who backed the Remain campaign in the run up to the 2016 in-or-out poll, launched a survey on his constituency website seeking local views on the possibility of a re-run of the historic vote on the UK's links with Brussels.He said he wanted to gauge opinion in his North East Bedfordshire patch after a number of constituents had contacted his office to express anger and concern about the progress with the country's withdrawal from the EU.But Eurosceptic Tory MPs accused him of breaching government policy given Theresa May's repeated rejection of demands for a second EU referendum.Tory MP and Leave campaigner Andrew Bridgen said: Alistair Burt is an arch-Europhile. I hope this is not an indication of the way Government policy is heading.Former Tory aide INFURIATES radio host in Brexit rowTrade expert predicts second Brexit referendum by end of 2018We haven't yet implemented the will of the people from the first referendum.I am not finding anyone in North West Leicestershire asking me for a second referendum.In fact, I am getting a lot of Remain voters telling me that the way the negotiations are going mean we cannot stay in the EU.They say that Brussels would treat us as a doormat if we stayed so we have got to get out.Alistair Burt has come under fire for asking voters for a second referendum  (Image: NC )Another senior Tory said: This is a complete breach of government policy. Alistair Burt needs to be reminded of his responsibilities under the principle of government collective responsibility.If he wants to keep his job, he should remove this survey immediately.A message on Mr Burt's website said: As discussions on Brexit continue, I have received many emails from constituents &ndash on both sides of the debate &ndash angry and concerned about how this process is progressing.I am keen to hear your views, and would be interested to see your answers to the questions below.MPs have backed the People's Vote campaign (Image:  )The survey then asked constituents to answer yes or no to the question: Do you support a further vote on the referendum?A second question asked: If there was a further vote, what should it cover?Four options were put forward by the website including a vote on the final deal, a re-run of the original referendum with in-out choices, a choice between three options of 'hard' Brexit, 'soft' Brexit or remaining in the EU, or having no further vote.Mr Burt's survey last night threatened to intensify the deepening Tory row over Europe.A second EU referendum in a new survey was posted (Image:  )A growing number of Eurosceptic Tories are concerned that the Prime Minister will come under pressure to grant a second referendum given the support for the move at the Westminster.Dozens of MPs from all the main political parties have backed the People's Vote campaign demanding a fresh poll even though both the Tory and Labour leaderships are opposed to the idea.Following yesterday's outcry, Mr Burt later updated his website to insist he was not in favour of a second referendum.He wrote: In view of the interest shown in the Brexit Survey I launched recently, I have made it clear to constituents who have written to me that I do not favour a second referendum.                'A coup by the RICH!' MEP warns of consequences of second Brexit vote                Tory MP SHUTS DOWN Alastair Campbell in fiery Brexit deateThe minister went on to set out his reasons for opposing a second referendum, including the fact that no mention of a second referendum was made at the original poll in 2016.Mr Burt also acknowledged a second referendum would not settle the issue and suggested a narrow vote to Remain could lead to calls for yet another poll.Neither the UK nor the EU benefits from prolonged, generational uncertainty of the UK seemingly unable to make its mind up, he saidMr Burt added: I have made repeatedly clear that the best way forward is to recognise that the UK remains deeply but almost evenly ided on the issue of membership of the EU.In 40 years of support for it, I and others have not been able to persuade the UK of its merits. I remain sorry about that, but accept it.And there&rsquos no going back. We should make the best of our situation and find a resolution for the best for both the UK and the EU and I am wholeheartedly behind the PM&rsquos efforts to do so.However, my constituents are entitled to their opinions and I&rsquom entitled to ask what they are, through a simple survey with a variety of options. That&rsquos all I have sought to do, and the survey has been out for some time with no adverse comment.In the referendum on the UK&rsquos membership of the EU in June 2016, 17.4million people voted to Leave the bloc while 16.1million voted to Remain.

title: brexit news motorists car tyre labels eu regulations
story: EU chiefs want to toughen regulations to ensure that all new tyres fitted to vehicles on public roads are printed with information about their fuel efficiency, safety and noise standards.And even though the UK is due to quit the EU next year, British drivers could still be affected by the change - expected in 2020 if agreed by MEPs - because Brussels regulations are due to remain in force after Brexit under Theresa May's plans.Campaigners from the Brexit-backing grassroots pressure group Get Britain Out claimed the move could add up to &pound15 to the price of a tyre for a middle-range family saloon through increased production and design costs.Jayne Adye, director of Get Britain Out, said: &ldquoThis proposed EU regulation demonstrates how out of touch the European Commission is with the real world.Motorists could be penalised by the EU regulations   (Image: NC)Whilst it may look good on paper over in Brussels, this regulation would harm British motorists and farmers burdened with extra costs.&ldquoThere are many pieces of legislation, such as this one, which are set to come into force before December 2020 and the end of the Brexit transition period.It is imperative we leave as soon as possible to avoid such red tape entering our statute book.She added: &ldquoThe Commission has no intention of stopping with this piece of regulation.                Cyclists should face same punishment as drivers, says motoring lawyer                 Car tax changes could see YOU charged based on the amount of miles ...The revised energy labels for tyres strengthen the requirements on fuel efficiency, noise and safety, and will apply to tyres on all road-using vehicles including cars, vans and lorries.EU officials say the new labelling will be beneficial for the environment by increasing fuel efficiency and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.&nbsp It will lead to CO2 savings equivalent of removing almost four million passenger cars from EU roads per year by 2030, according to Brussels estimates.The RAC last night backed the new labelling system. RAC spokesman Simon Williams said: &ldquoStrengthening the tyre labelling regulations is good news for UK motorists and road safety generally.Currently, there is no requirement for tyre fitters to show labels at the point of purchase so motorists are oblivious to the pros and cons of the tyres they are buying.As a result few motorists are shown the labels when buying tyres, leaving them completely in the dark about the three ratings of fuel efficiency, wet grip and passing noise.Updating the regulations should fix this by making it mandatory for tyre labels to be shown to motorists in all situations.&ldquoInformation on tyres&rsquo snow and ice performance is going to be included which will be very beneficial.The labels are also being future-proofed as the amended regulations allow for the addition of other useful information such as ratings for mileage, wear and a potential indication for re-treaded tyres.                Bulgarian jailed for Ayrshire crash that killed pensioner                British motorist lands &pound36,000 in speeding fines in just FOUR hours...The International Tyre Manufacturers' Association has also backed the proposals.In a statement to the EU earlier this year, the association's president Alfred Graham said: &ldquoITMA is fully supportive of any measure that improves tyre safety, an objective the introduction the tyre-labelling regulation sought to achieve.If that means more can be done to increase motorists&rsquo awareness and understanding of the information on the labels, ITMA will gladly play its part.A critical element of the scheme was to inform consumers of the relative value and environmental benefits of the tyres they are considering buying, so they might be able to make an informed purchasing decision.Achieving that is essential if further performance ratings are to be added to the labelling, a proposal which ITMA also believes has merit, especially for winter and re-tread tyres.Fundamentally, of course, the accurate and consistent assessment of tyre performance is critical and to the benefit of all parties.Should viable means to enhancing existing practises be found, ITMA would once again be supportive of such changes.

title: Blindness cure sight restored mice gene therapy
story: This allowed mice to regain their vision after about six weeks (Image: )A team of US scientists from the National Institutes of Health used a gene injection to reprogramme dumb non-seeing retinal cells, and then use them to replace damaged light-sensitive rod cells.&nbspThis is the first time researchers have managed to replace damaged retinal cells, leading to hopes that the same process could one day be applied to humans.&nbspThe study demonstrated that it is possible to restore lost light-sensitive cells in the eye, by putting a gene into the retinal cells and using it to reorientate them.&nbspThis allowed mice to regain their vision after about six weeks.&nbsp                Punish patients who miss appointments with &pound5 says GPHowever during the study only rods were restored, which provide vision in low light.&nbspBut the researchers hope conserving the rods will also protect cones, the other type of retinal cell which is integral to sight.&nbspDr Bo Chen, one of the researchers, said: &ldquoThis is very powerful cell repair machinery.&nbsp&ldquoThe major strength of the research is this can be applied to the wider spectrum of retinal degenerative diseases.&nbspIf this works this could transform the way we treat patients with retinal disease (Image: )&ldquoIf this works, this could transform the way we treat patients with retinal disease and possibly learn how to cure other types of eye disease like glaucoma.Dr Chen added that the human eye has the same essential structure, though the process cannot yet be replicated in humans.&nbspHe explained: &ldquoThe basic structure is still there.&nbsp&ldquoBut for some reason it is inhibited.&nbspThe scientists studied zebrafish as part of their investigation, which already have the ability to convert retinal nerve cells into the vital rod cells.&nbspHelen Lee, from the Royal National Institute of Blind People welcomed the news saying:&nbspThe scientists studied zebrafish as part of their investigation (Image:  )&ldquoClearly it is still at a very early stage.&nbsp&ldquoBut at some point in the future stem cell treatment may become part of the armoury of treatments for sight-threatening eye conditions.If the process can be extended to humans, with new rod cells being created, it should be able to give sight to many of those who are born blind and restore it in others.&nbsp

title: Brexit news Chris Grayling UK EU withdrawal Chequers latest Theresa May
story: Transport Secretary Chris Grayling said he would be willing to accept a certain degree of alignment with EU regulation after Brexit to avoid disruption to businesses.Mr Grayling, who campaigned to Leave during the 2016 referendum, argued a compromise could ensure Britain secures a sensible relationship with the European Union in the future.Speaking to the Today programme, the Brexiteer minister said: I didn&rsquot campaign to leave the EU in order to have a different specification of motorcar in France and in the UK and so I can accept having alignment on the technical specifications of manufactured goods, if that is the price we need to pay in order to have a sensible relationship in the future.None of us wants no-deal, none of us are working towards that. I think it would be damaging for both this country and the European Union.                Rees-Mogg spearheads new Brexit plan with 'POSITIVE' future                BREXIT LIVE: New High Court legal challenge to Brexit LAUNCHED Mr Grayling also voiced his support for the latest Brexit blueprint put forward by Theresa May as it would offer us a way to reach an agreement with the European Union.The new plan would see Britain maintain close commercial ties with Brussels through a free trade area managed by a common rulebook &ndash a move Brexiteers have blasted as a betrayal of demands from Leave voters.But the Tory frontbencher defended the Chequers deal, saying the Government will now work to gain the support of the party.He continued: There are clearly things that I wouldn&rsquot be happy to accept but the Prime Minister has been very clear that she is not asking this country to accept those.&ldquoThere are people who want us to remain in the Single Market, that requires continued free movement, that would be unacceptable to me, that would be unacceptable to the Government and that would be unacceptable to the people who voted to leave.Brexit news: Chris Grayling said he would be willing to remain aligned to the EU to avoid disruption (Image: BBC&bull)Mr Grayling added: I think we can get there we just have to work very hard this autumn to achieve it.&ldquoWe are working very hard to make sure we are ready for all eventualities, including no-deal, but of course if there is no deal and we can&rsquot reach an agreement it has a big negative effect on countries like Belgium, France and the Netherlands, none of us wants that.&ldquoIt is in everybody&rsquos interests that we have a good, sensible, balanced, stable relationship for the future.Mrs May has been facing increasing pressure from Brexit hard-liners in her party to change her proposal.A faction of Brexiteer dissidents, spearheaded by Jacob Rees-Mogg, is working to create an &ldquoalternative view to the Government&rsquos White Paper.Still in the development stages, the policy paper they aim to publish is understood to follow a Canadian-style free trade agreement, but only if the EU compromises on demands over the Irish border.As many as 80 backbench Tories could support the plan in open defiance of the Government's position on Brexit.Such a model could allow tariff-free trade without the UK remaining part of the EU's single market or customs union.One European Research Group source was quoted by yesterday as saying: &ldquoWe have made it very clear that we do not accept the Chequers proposals but there is an acknowledgement that we need to make the case for an alternative.&ldquoThe tricky bit is coming to a common position that everyone can sign up to. But I&rsquom confident that we should be able to achieve that.Another source was quoted as saying: &ldquoWe are working to come up with a positive policy paper that will take a realistic approach outlining what is acceptable in line with the referendum result.But the European Research Group is facing a challenge from a rival faction of MPs committed to backing the Prime Minister&rsquos Brexit plans.The new Brexit Delivery Group, set up by backbenchers Andrew Percy and Nick Boles, is seeking to unite Tory MPs who voted both Leave and Remain in the 2016 EU referendum.

title: a level results grade boundaries ucas points track clearing explained
story: Today is the day anxious teenagers will find out if months of hard work have been worth it.Students across the nation will finally figure out how their exams went, with results beginning to go live at 8am, Thursday, August 16.The results will be out on UCAS feature, Track, from 8am, but you can also contact you collect or university to check if you have been accepted.When you have received your results you, head to UCAS to calculate your UCAS points.                A-levels results day 2018: What are the A-level grade boundaries? O...                A Levels 2018 results LIVE: Latest as UK students discover gradesA-level results day: Students will find out how their exams went today (Image: )UCAS pointsThe UCAS Tariff points are allocated to qualifications generally studied doing your A-levels.To work out how many UCAS points your qualifications are worth you need to:1. Select your qualification from the drop-down list.A-level results day 2018: The results will be on UCAS feature, Track (Image: )2. Enter the subject you're studying (this is optional).3. Select your grade from the drop-down list &ndash the Tariff points for this qualification will display automatically next to your grade.4. When you've entered all your qualifications, click on the &ldquonext button.Be aware that a lot of the qualifications are not on the Tariff points, and this does not mean you have not been accepted into the university of your choice.                A Level results day 2018: UCAS Clearing - how does Clearing work?                Students can get A-Level &lsquoA&rsquo mark with FIFTY PERCENT in some exams Some universities and colleges use UCAS points in their entry requirements, which means you need to check how many points your qualifications are worth.See more on that HERE.&nbspGrade boundariesThe grade boundaries shows the minimum number of marks required for each grade.A-level results day 2018: The results came out at 8am this morning (Image: )Grade boundaries will be published from 8am today, same as the exam results, and are available on each exam board&rsquos website.Each exam board has its own grade boundary.Previously the boundaries have been realised online the day before students receive their A-level results, but since 2017 it has been changed to be published the same day.The different grade boundaries used are OCR, EdexcelPearson, AQA and CCEA.You can read more about this on our  grade boundaries guide.A-level results day 2018: Youngsters will find out if months of hard work has paid off (Image: )How does UCAS Clearing work?UCAS, the website every university student in the UK uses to apply for a place, has a system to ensure students find a university with the grades they have achieved.UCAS Clearing gives students the chance to change their mind about which university to attend, to apply for a degree at the last minute or to alter choices once grades have been revealed.Using the dedicated website and your already existing UCAS account, you can search for courses.Once you have found a course and wish to apply - there will be an &lsquoAdd A Clearing Choice&rsquo option found on the &lsquoNext Steps&rsquo page.However, unlike the usual five choices you get when first applying with UCAS, Clearing only allows one choice.If you don&rsquot progress with your first choice Clearing university, you are allowed to choose another.

title: brexit negotiations theresa may eu leaders salzburg summit september
story: According to diplomatic sources, suggestions Mrs May could negotiate with the 27 other EU heads of state and government at a summit in Salzburg have been rejected out of hand.One European source said: &ldquoThat is completely ridiculous, that is complete overspin of Salzburg.&ldquoIt would mean that we would ditch our negotiating approach of the last two years and discuss at 28 instead of 27 to one, and I don&rsquot see why this would happen.The comments came after Mrs May&rsquos office announced Brexit would be on the agenda at the September 20 talks after after discussions with Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz.                 Britain will THRIVE: Hunt dismisses No Deal scaremongering                Is MI6 BUGGING the Brexit talks? EU officials raise concerns European Union leaders will discuss Brexit when they next meet in the Austrian city of Salzburg on Sept. 20, British Prime Minister Theresa May&rsquos office saidA spokesman said: &ldquoThe summit will also cover illegal migration, and on this the Prime Minister confirmed that the UK will continue to work closely with the EU now and after Brexit.Brexit talks resume in Brussels today with the aim of reaching a deal by the autumn.EU bosses have always insisted all formal talks are led by chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier and while Mrs May is allowed to update EU leaders on her plans at quarterly EU summits, she is not in the room for discussions.Theresa May and Sebastian Kurz in Salzburg last month (Image: )Theresa May wants direct talks with fellow EU leaders (Image: )Officials expect this approach to be continued at Salzburg where an informal summit on September 20 is being held to discuss the migration crisis.The meeting has been organised by Austria, which currently holds the EU rotating presidency, but it will be for the European council president Donald Tusk to decide whether to add Brexit to the agenda.Salzburg comes four weeks before an EU summit in Brussels at which Mr Barnier hopes to strike a deal.Many in Brussels expect the deadline to slip to November or even December, squeezing the time available to ratify the text ahead of the UK&rsquos departure on March 29, 2019.                Germany MUST pay for Brexit EU budget shortfall, claims expert                Fury as top Tory launches second EU referendum bidMrs May has tried to get round Mr Barnier by appealing directly to national capitals for greater flexibility, a strategy continued by Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt who is on a three-day Brexit tour on the continent this week.Few are expecting a dramatic breakthrough from this week&rsquos low-key Brexit negotiations in Brussels, which will be led by officials rather than Mr Barnier and the new Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab.The Irish border issue tops the agenda for today&rsquos talks with both sides deeply ided over how to avoid customs checks at the crossing.Tomorrow&rsquos sessions will be devoted to the UK&rsquos future relationship with the EU as outlined in Mrs May&rsquos Chequers blueprint.Dominic Raab and Michel Barnier (Image: )Brussels sees serious flaws in the Chequers plan and has dismissed Mrs May&rsquos customs ideas as unworkable but negotiators have not entirely written off the plan and see the kernel of a free-trade agreement.EU officials insist they cannot break up the EU&rsquos single market and its &ldquofour freedoms of goods, capital, services and people.A diplomat said: &ldquoI can&rsquot imagine we would walk away from that.&ldquoIt is the raison d&rsquo&ecirctre of the EU. We can&rsquot have Brexit threaten our political and economic system.

title: a level 2018 results how to resit when to resit a levels
story: Not all students will receive the the results they had hoped for today but luckily there are ways you can still get into your dream university.Resitting an exam might not be what already anxious students had hoped for but many people are in the same boat.If resitting is not an option, you can look through UCAS Clearing to see if there is anything suitable for you.Going into a full-time job or an apprenticeship is also an option, if you want to leave the time as an A-level student behind you.                What are the A-level grade boundaries? OCR, Edexcel, AQA and more                A-level results: Grade boundaries and UCAS points explainedA-level 2018 results: You can resit your exams if you didn't get accepted into your dream university (Image: )How and when to resit your A-levelsThe first thing you should do when resitting your A-level exams is to talk to your college or school first, as you might be able to retake your exam there.Not all schools offers this but luckily, there are tons of other options.If you are not planning on sitting the exams in your old school or college, you can do it at an exam centre but you will need to provide the centre with your old candidate details.A-level 2018 results: If resitting is not an option, you can look through UCAS Clearing (Image: )The downside of retaking A-level exams at an independent college is that it can cost a lot of money.A-levels can only be done once per year and exams normally happen in June.This means you can enrol to retake the exams the following year.The option of taking A-level exams in January is unfortunately no longer available.Remember you can only resit your exams once.                Students can get A-Level &lsquoA&rsquo mark with FIFTY PERCENT in some exams                 A Level 2018 results LIVE: Latest as UK students discover gradesA-level 2018 results: A-levels can only be done once per year, and normally happens in June (Image: )In most cases you will have to retake the whole A-level, and end up with two grades, one from your original grade and one from your retake.In some subjects you might be able to use assessments submitted in your old course, as long a they are non-examined assessments.When you have decided on resitting your exams, you need to officially decline any offers you have received from universities by September 20.Your school or college will most likely be able to help you with further advice on what to do, so talk to an exams co-ordinator about what your best options are.Bear in mind, although most universities accept resits, offers might be slightly higher.The upside to retaking your A-level can be an opportunity to show the university you are committed to your studies, and shows independence.

story: For some poor students, A-level results day turned out to be a disappointment rather than a celebration.If you did not get the results you were hoping for, try not to worry.Some students have been left confused after receiving the grades from their exams, wondering if they have passed A-levels.Read below to find out what grade you need to be able to advance into higher education. title: Weather forecast UK Met Office latest heatwave hot weather august 2018 weekend
story: Freakishly hot weather could hold out through September and possibly into October, according to some long-range forecasters.A plume of warm, sultry air will sweep into Britain during the middle of next week just as the nation starts to cool down.Temperatures could reach their highest so far this summer with the 38.5C (101.3F) record still under threat, experts say.Only Scotland and parts of northern England will escape the sweltering steam-bath although it will be warmer than average across much of the UK.                UK HOT weather forecast: Britain faces 43C temp as HOTTEST spell hits                UK weather forecast: Britain braces for CONTINENTAL SCORCHERJames Madden, forecaster for Exacta Weather, warned Britain could be facing another lengthy heatwave.He said: &ldquoOur models show we are about to go into another period of prolonged summery weather, there is a growing likelihood we could see another extreme heat surge during the second half of this month.&ldquoIt is not out of the question that Britain will bask in some of the highest temperatures of summer to date, even beating those seen over the past two months.&ldquoThere is every chance this summer will come in as the hottest on record as temperatures rise back into the mid 30Cs at the very least.&ldquoLonger-range projections show the possibility of warm weather continuing into the start of the meteorological autumn and even into October.Britons have been urged to make the most of a brief cooler spell which will bring a drop in temperatures over the next couple of days.UK weather forecast: Britain is set to sizzle as the UK heatwave returns (Image: NETWEATHER)Torrential rain will hammer swathes of the country as a cold front moves in from the Atlantic on Wednesday night.Northern Britain will be first in the firing line before downpours pelt the south and southeast on Thursday morning.The rain will clear through the day making way for much fresher air to bring temperatures down widely, the Met Office said.Meteorologist Bonnie Diamond said: &ldquoQuite an active front will move over Wales and northern England on Wednesday evening bringing some heavy rain.&ldquoThis will move into the southeast of the country through Thursday morning and it will be a much fresher day with maximum temperatures of around 21C (69.8F).&ldquoFriday is looking more unsettled in the north again with a drier, nicer day forecast elsewhere although it will still feel fresher compared to the start of the week.                BBC weather forecast: Temperatures to SOAR &ndash but not before a storm                Four more years of heatwaves on wayUK weather forecast: Temperatures are set to soar back to 30C this week (Image: NETWEATHER)Rain will continue to pelt Scotland and northwestern England over the weekend with sunshine confined to the south, she said.South-eastern England will hold on to the fine weather into next week as temperatures start to head upwards, she added.She said: &ldquoFrom the middle of next week onwards there will be a good deal of dry, bright weather in the southeast as a result this part of the country will be back to warm or very warm temperatures.&ldquoIt is also going to be humid as tropical air moves into southern Britain, later next week we are expecting temperatures in the high 20Cs.&ldquoThe longer-range outlook shows there is a possibility of the warm or very warm weather lasting in the southeast, it will be more unsettled in northern parts of the country.Warm weather will hold out at least until the end of the month meaning Britons will enjoy another bank holiday scorcher.

story: Ebenezer was born on August 16, 1831, in Hull, England.At 27 he moved to Barnes, London, where he worked as a solicitor and rowed along the Thames in his free time.Ebenezer made his first stamp on the sporting world when he founded the Barnes and Mortlake Regatta in 1862 and competed in the Grand Challenge Cup at Henley in 1864.His real legacy, however, lies in being the first person to write the rules of football.                Google Doodle celebrates influential philosopher Ibn Sina - who was...Before Ebenezer set the rules of the &lsquobeautiful game&rsquo to paper, football was said to be a chaotic sport with no organised competitions.But the lawyer saw the potential in the sport, and formed the Barnes Club, a founding member of the FA, in 1862.In 1863, as captain of the club, he wrote to Bell&rsquos Life newspaper, proposing governing body for the game.In an attempt to garner financial and academic support, he appealed to some of the nation&rsquos most prestigious schools to get involved, but was rebuffed.Undeterred, Ebenezer convened a meeting at the Freemason&rsquos Tavern in Holborn on October 26, 1863, which would go down in history.Ebenezer Cobb Morley: Ebenezer set the rules of the &lsquobeautiful game&rsquo to paper (Image: GettyTwitter@ForStatue)The meeting was attended by representatives of future football giants, including Blackheath, Perceval House, Kensington School, the War Office, Crystal Palace, the Crusaders, Charterhouse and No Names of Kilburn.With this, the Football Association was born, with Ebenezer at the helm as its first secretary and then president.His original draft of 23 rules included a provision allowing players to &ldquohack the front of the leg, which proved controversial.The isive rule was eventually scrapped, and the finalised version was published in the FA&rsquos December 1863 pamphlet, Laws of the Game.These rules were adopted across London and, eventually, spread across the world. title: the sun reader letters boris burka
story: But there has been a groundswell of support for BoJo from ordinary people, fed up at what they see as attacks on freedom of expression and the British way of life.This is what Sun readers have to say about the issue, and Brexit-backer Boris:BORIS Johnson has a dig at burka-wearing Muslims and our elite shake with fear. Don’t they know many thousands of people agree with him? Or do they chose to again ignore the people of this country? Any movement on Boris from the out-of-touch Government will cost them dear.SO Dominic Grieve has threatened to quit Parliament if Boris Johnson became PM. I can think of no better reason for wishing him success.BANG on Boris, about the burka. It being worn in public is scary for children who see it.FREEDOM of speech must not be compromised – and there can be no question of legal action being taken against Boris Johnson, it would be prejudiced by all the attacks on him.THIS week it has been especially hard to be a Muslim woman. Apparently I am not getting the joke, I’m over sensitive, bullied, oppressed, unintegrated, politically motivated, dividing Britain – this list goes on. Perhaps Boris Johnson’s Etonian education did not enable him to understand that in polite society it’s rude to comment with ridicule on the way people dress.ONE thing critics of Boris Johnson’s burka comment overlook is the impact of burka-wearers on those who are deaf and rely on seeing facial expressions, and lip-reading.THE do-gooders complaining about Boris are fanning the flames of hatred by highlighting issues that one wouldn’t really think about. Talk about “integration” appears to be one-sided and discriminatory towards the indigenous people. There is some equilibrium lacking in our “fair, just and equal” land of ours.WHILE I am not sure Boris used a good choice of words likening women in burkas to pillar boxes, he was right that we are frightened by what it represents. We must not destroy Boris, he is good for the people of this country, he cares. He must also be allowed to speak honestly, he has nothing to apologise for.LIGHTEN up, Boris spoke the thoughts of many millions of Brits. If making a gaffe was against the law, Prince Philip could have been banged up in the Tower of London on many occasions during the last 50 years. He wrote the book on it.Boris might have an agenda – what politician doesn’t? – but this mustn’t mean people don’t have a right to voice criticism. Face veils in public, and burkas, are not religious requirements and we must have the right to criticise the wearers.IF I was Boris Johnson, I would agree to attend the diversity training some have suggested . . . and then tear the training session to pieces.I SAW Ranvir Singh berating her guests on morning TV for daring to agree with Boris Johnson? I wonder what her bosses would say if she suggested that she presented her programme wearing a burka. I think we all know the answer to that.PHIL GROWDENNOTHING Theresa May says can be taken at face value. Not so long ago, she promised to stop the witch-hunt of British soldiers, who have seen action and survived in many parts of the world. However, the victimisation of our veterans continues unabated. They are now joined by Boris Johnson, who has frequently ignited the Prime Minister’s wrath and must therefore, be thrown to the wolves.A BUS company has apologised after a driver told a woman to remove her niqab. So would a bank apologise if a security guard asked a man to remove his ski mask?HOW would I stand as a Christian male finding a Muslim lady, dressed in a burka, having a heart attack? Would I be allowed to remove her veil to perform mouth-to-mouth?THE controversy surrounding Boris Johnson’s burka comments has reached ridiculous heights. Police conducting an investigation. Really?IF Theresa May had the guts to ban the burka like a lot of other countries, we might not be having this discussion about what Boris Johnson said.SOMETHING featureless with a rectangular hole in it can resemble a letter box, there’s probably one on your front door, go and have a look. It has also been known for the person inside to be a terrorist, not an innocent woman. Stop being so pathetic, have a sense of humour, act like adultsI READ about a motorcyclist at a filling station having to remove his crash helmet while a woman (who could have been a criminal’s getaway driver) filling up at the pump next to him was wearing a burka. Meanwhile Boris’s remarks are causing hysteria.I HAVE been visiting garden centres and supermarket car parks in my car, which is bedecked with Brexit stickers, asking many people their opinion on the Boris situation. For Boris, I find there is a great deal of love out there. For the Chequers “deal” there is none.IT’S true that Boris Johnson has used strong language but Muslim terrorists are doing far worse things than robbing banks, by committing terrorist atrocities. It would be a sad day when the Muslim community can’t take such a comment, especially when many Muslim women, in my view, do not want this clothing themselves.IT’S confirmed, lunatics are ruining the country. We have the enemy (EU) knocking art the door and all the idiots can find to discuss is Boris Johnson’s perfectly fair comment. If it wasn’t so serious it would be funny. Brexit should be top of the agenda.THERE are easily as many people who agree with BoJo’s comments as those who don’t. So why is it those who don’t will instigate an investigation, leaving those who do without a voice? Even senior Muslims and imams have said that the burka is not a requirement in Islam, so why is it we only tend to listen to those who are offended?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the last leg ally ross
story: You expect this reaction, obviously, from news organisations who have to fill endless blank hours with something during silly season.The really depressing thing, though, was that a late-night Channel 4 “comedy” show and its presenters were the most outraged of them all.I’m talking, of course, about The Last Leg which, for reasons that still escape me, genuinely fancies itself as one of television’s edgiest and funniest shows.It’s not, clearly. The Last Leg is a television safe space, the authentic voice of the PC establishment and as predictable as the sun rising in the morning.So you knew, long before Friday’s transmission, that they’d be targeting Boris, who is a thousand times funnier and edgier than anyone on this show, in his own way.Nearly a whole working week host Adam Hills and his two mates had to prepare some decent material as well, and this was the best three professional comedians could do.Alex Brooker: “The burka is an item of clothing worn by a human being, the other is a postbox, you f***ing idiot.”Adam Hills: “I’d much rather sit next to a person in burka than a p***k in a suit.”Josh Widdicombe: “Theresa May has only just realised Boris is a t**t, so she should apologise as well.”On and on it went, for 12 minutes and 54 seconds, a figure I mention because I’ve had the clock on this lot, and if you want to know exactly how much of a toss they really give about religious sensitivities then it’s best measured by the fact this series of The Last Leg has devoted just 65 hand-wringing seconds to the anti-Semitic poison infecting the Labour Party.It was crammed hurriedly into the previous episode, which was worth watching just to see Adam Hills describe Corbyn’s handling of this crisis as “a faux pas”, (which isn’t French for “shameful cluster-f***”) and the C4 audience react with evident discomfort because he’d drawn attention to the Labour leader’s failings and, therefore, broken one of comedy’s secret and golden rules.If you doubted these rules exist, incidentally, then ever the virtue-signalling fool, Adam Hills was good enough to spell them out for us on Friday.“Every religion should be open to ridicule . . . but you kind of need to be in the club.“Alex and I can make jokes about disabilities as we’re technically disabled.”Boris, he then explained, can’t make jokes about burkas, ’cos he’s “a white Etonian”, nor could comedy giant Rowan Atkinson defend him, as he was “a white man who lives in Oxford and drives an F1 car”.Even if we ignore the fact he’s assumed that all Muslims are black, something pretty staggering is going on here.For Mary Whitehouse, in all her pearl-clutching glory, never imagined anything quite as Draconian and controlling as this form of satirical Apartheid.Adam Hills has a point, though, when he uses the word “club”. That’s exactly what television comedy has become.A closed, left-wing shop where you don’t even bother joining the audience unless you follow the rigid “Tories and Brexit are evil” party line.This is not creating comedy, it’s policing it, and also the reason why applause has replaced laughter on all those Channel 4 and BBC news satires which have failed to realise there is only one simple rule to be observed when creating these shows: Make it funny, dumbo.I would suggest, at this point, Adam Hills gets off his moral high horse, for once, and gives this “funny” idea a go.But then I could also ask Boris to have a crack at anchoring the British women’s 4x100m relay team to gold at the next Olympics, wearing a burka, and I’d know there was only the remotest chance of one ever happening.Run Boris, run.MEANWHILE, back on Channel 4’s Meet The Drug Lords: Inside The Real Narcos, Jason “Foxy” Fox was with the Colombian navy this week and desperate for a look inside one of the incredible home-made submarines they’d confiscated from drug-smugglers.“Is it locked?”“Yes.”And there’ll be more Bafta-worthy action from Foxy and his forward-planning department this week, I’m sure.EVER since it discovered that Danny Dyer was the rightful heir to the English throne, Who Do You Think You Are? has been struggling to find a purpose, or indeed a celebrity, who could see the bigger picture.That special someone who would acknowledge history’s great events with more than a few “wows” and shrugs and not think their own career made all of their ancestors’ suffering worthwhile.Finally, last night, they found him.Judge Robert Rinder, who as well as having the best brain at ITV (Luna the Labrador off This Morning has the second best) also turns out to be a natural television journalist, telling the story of his maternal great-grandfather, Israel, and his beloved grandfather, Morris, simply, beautifully and without ever letting the details overwhelm him.The former fled revolutionary Latvia at the turn of the last century.The latter’s entire family was wiped out in Treblinka’s gas chambers.Yet he somehow survived the Buchen-wald, Theresienstadt and Schlieben concentration camps and made it to Britain, which offered him salvation, friendship, justice and, above all, a sense that “life is worth living” that has been passed down through eternally grateful generations.It’s a remarkable story, so if you missed it, try to catch tonight’s repeat (BBC1, 11.25pm).SCENES and characters the viewers are unlikely to forget in a hurry on the final episode of BBC2’s wonderful Travels In Trumpland With Ed Balls.First stop, the President’s Mar-a-Lago compound in Florida, where Ed spent the most uncomfortable night of his life, since Strictly, at a one-year-in-office party for Trump, with Toni Holt Kramer and a group of fans who were called The Trumpettes, but could well have been the provisional wing of The Golden Girls.If you thought they were a bit sinister, though, he was then off squirrel hunting in the forests of Georgia with two hillbillies who might not have been plucking banjos but they certainly had the mad cackling laughs and slightly unsettling line in hospitality.“Are you ready to be a man today, Ed?” asked one, as you began to wonder if he could escape with his dignity intact, let alone blend in with the local gene pool.Then he suddenly reappeared – and this was a masterstroke – wearing a Norwich City scarf.Scrub everything I ever said about Ed Balls.The man’s a diplomatic genius.Sent in by Rob Milner, East Yorkshire. Picture research: Alfie SnellingTHIS Morning, Wednesday:Gok Wan: “Coming up, Ninja nanas, in a minute, John Torode’s in the Lake District at 11.45, and we’ve got the return of the Hawaiian shirt at midday.“First, would you like to live ten years longer?”Ten years? Right now I’m ambivalent abOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: first part time jobs sun writers
story: The number of 16 to 17-year-olds taking part-time jobs has more than halved since 1997, dropping from 42 per cent to 18 per cent. It means young people are missing out on essential skills as they approach adulthood.GRANT ROLLINGS asked five Sun columnists what their first part-time jobs were and the valuable lessons they learned – from being polite to skiving.I ALWAYS had a summer job, usually it meant working full-time hours on my normal Saturday job as holiday cover. This was either in a boutique such as Chelsea Girl or in BHS, where I worked on the sweetie counter.I coped with the boredom by sneakily munching on the best chocolate sweets from the pick-and-mix. I also worked as a waitress in a trendy Glasgow eaterie during the holidays.All of these jobs gave me the most enormous respect for the men and women who toil for long hours, often dealing with unreasonable members of the public for too little pay and not much prospect of promotion.Working in the service industry taught me the power of a disarming smile, and proved that my old granny’s saying that “you get more in life from sugar than vinegar” could not be more true.Grumpy customers demanding refunds and diners moaning that they had been waiting too long for their main course were usually placated with a swift apology and a promise to sort things out.A major restaurant blunder could often be smoothed over with a free coffee or pudding.MY favourite summer job came in 1977. I was a traffic enumerator for Middlesbrough Council. That meant I spent all day counting cars. All the way up one side of Linthorpe Road, all the way back down the other.I had to write down all the number plates. In the end, I got a bit bored and spent the time hanging out at my mate’s T-shirt shop or Fearnley Records and made the numbers up, always remembering to have them end in the local codes of HN or (I think) XG. I hope the council thought it worthwhile.It was better than the glue factory, where I’d been very briefly working on a weighbridge. Foreman pressed a button and this vast door opened and thousands of rotting animal carcasses fell out. I can still smell it now, all these years later. I passed out — soft lad, you see.Or there was working the nightshift pricing cans of food and stuff in Hintons, the local convenience store. Every time I turned up, the manager would say, ‘Here he is, the poor man’s Rod Stewart’.A friend of mine, Mark, had a much better summer job.He was a Club 18-30 holiday rep. He shagged 21 girls in 25 days, which gave me my first story to sell to the national newspapers.MY first holiday job was in the summer of 1985 when I was 16 years old. I had already been turned down from working at Waitrose in Enfield Town on the basis I was “too glamorous”.That just goes to show how far we have come in such a short time. I have never set foot in a Waitrose since that day because I was beyond furious. Anyway, the job I did get was working in a hairdresser’s on Goodge Street in London.My journey involved three changes and about 14 stops every day. The job was meant to be answering the phone, sweeping up and generally helping out, but before the end of the first week I was running the till, the appointment system, cashing up and generally managing the place.The only thing I could not do was cut hair, but that didn’t stop me cutting my friends’ hair — with very mixed results, more bad than good — on the basis I worked in a hairdresser’s so they thought I should. I remember the liberating feeling of earning my own money, it gave me the greatest sense of independence, self-esteem and self-belief.I worked out I was actually good in a work environment, talking to people — for example, talking women into perms they didn’t want — being responsible, handling money and making a difference to my employer.The biggest transition we make in our lives is leaving education to go into the workplace, and summer jobs prepare you for this.I HAD dozens of summer jobs, from working as a scaffolder’s mate with a convicted murderer, who kept a pistol in the glove compartment of his Ford Escort, to donning a white suit and Geiger counter to carry out maintenance on the core of the main reactor at a nuclear power station.I learned a hundred things from each and every job, but it was working as a grocery assistant at my local supermarket that had the most impact.My best friend and I both got jobs there at the same time. He was a star performer at school, a brilliant academic, but he couldn’t take the pace and got fired after a couple of months.It was incredibly hard, repetitive work.The manager was an ex-Army major — very strict on haircuts, discipline and stealing.There was always the prospect of the Tannoy announcement “customer service one hundred”, which was code for a shoplifter having been spotted.All the male floor staff were required to assemble at till number one to tackle the suspect, who would sometimes become violent.I was much happier making the cheese look pretty and eventually became the ruler of the entire soft dairy aisle — a project I’m still working on.I WAS 13 in Brownes Wine bar, Stafford Street, Derby, summer 1987, some years before it burned down in mysterious circumstances (has a bar ever burnt down innocently?). I was chief bottler-up.This involved the soul-sapping exercise of sifting through bins taller than me for all the recyclable bottles from the previous night’s festivities and putting them in their correct crates. This took all morning and you ended up cut to shreds and stinking of Britvic and Schlitz.I was then asked to be the cook — this involved microwaving lasagne for drunk people. I was paid the princely sum of £3 per hour. I realised how crap this was, so one scorching Saturday I nicked the shampoo that came with my dad’s company car and took advantage of the sketchy Eighties attitude to drink-driving and washed all the customers’ cars in the car park for a fiver a pop.I literally cleaned up. It was the greatest Dragons’ Den moment I’ve ever had. I waxed on and off all day, rinsing my dad of his prized BMW product. He arrived to pick me up and I was minted. A 13-year-old with £64 in his pocket. That coveted Swatch would finally be mine.He then told me the dog had been run over, so that’s another memory ruined.Thanks for reminding me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
