title: face up what youve done
story: News'Face up to what you’ve done': Speedboat crash victim's heartbroken family urge fugitive killer to face justiceEXCLUSIVE: Charlotte Brown’s older sisters Katie, 29, and Vicky, 31, from Dartford, Kent, write an open letter to Jack ShepherdShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJulie McCaffrey22:30, 15 AUG 2018NewsTragic Charlotte Brown (middle) seen here with her sisters Katie (left), and Vicky (right)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen beloved sister and daughter Charlotte “Charli” Brown was killed in a speedboat crash on the Thames in London, her family were heartbroken. The 24-year-old was on a first date with web designer Jack Shepherd, whom she met online. He was trying to impress her with the champagne-fulled trip past the Houses of Parliament but drove at twice the speed limit, before the boat hit a log and tipped over. Shepherd, 30, went on the run instead of facing trial but was found guilty of manslaughter by gross negligence in his absence and jailed for six years. His refusal to face justice has left Charli’s family grief-stricken, frustrated, and with endless unanswered questions about that night in December 2015. Here Charli’s older sisters Katie, 29, and Vicky, 31, from Dartford, Kent, write an open letter to Shepherd.   Dear Jack Shepherd,  We both want you to know the terrible impact losing Charli has had on our lives. Katie heard the news of her death after a morning teaching science to secondary school children. A colleague gave her the message: “Please call your mum – &shysomething has happened to your sister.” She wondered if Vicky, who was eight-and-a-half months pregnant, had her baby prematurely. But as soon as Katie heard mum’s sobs and words: “It’s Charli”, she said: “What has he done?” Call it intuition or a premonition, but somehow Katie just knew something had gone terribly wrong the night before. It began during your date when Charli started sending WhatsApp messages telling of the food you ate at the restaurant, and champagne on the speedboat.  That evening, Katie’s second last message to Charli said: “Please let me know you have you survived this &shyescapade?” Charli didn’t answer. That night Katie couldn’t sleep. First thing the next day, she texted her concern: “Charli, are you alive?” That message wasn’t delivered to Charli’s phone, found in her pocket when they pulled her body from the river. Vicky was having a check up at the maternity hospital when she took mum’s call. She had a panic attack. Vicky remembers nothing except the sound of her own wailing. Hearing our baby sister was dead was the worst moment of our lives, until we had to identify her body. We went to the mortuary together with our parents, all hoping it wasn’t our Charli. As soon as we walked into the room and saw her, Mum and Vicky collapsed. Such deep trauma was dangerous for Vicky at such a late stage in pregnancy.  Her due date was December 29. But because of the distress caused by losing Charli, Vicky suffered a series of mini strokes and was admitted to hospital on December 20. She was induced for her and her baby’s safety, and because Charli’s funeral was planned for January 5 2016, and Vicky was terrified she’d go into labour as we said our final goodbyes. Because of you, Charli never met her gorgeous youngest nephew Edward, who was born on Boxing Day. Now Edward is two, the same age as your child who is growing up fatherless. Coming back to serve your time, and seeing your child, is surely better than a lifetime on the run, constantly looking over your shoulder? We urge you directly: give us answers and give yourself up. To any of your friends reading this, please know the net is closing in so you’re just delaying the inevitable. Jack, you’re young so facing justice and serving your time still gives you a chance of having a life, career and family.  Your reckless and cavalier attitude robbed Charli of that chance. But you can never take our memories of our glamorous, bubbly little sister. We remember Charli’s lovely confidence which made her comfortable meeting Vicky’s in-laws for the first time wearing huge rollers in her hair. We can laugh remembering her fearsome competitiveness playing crazy golf. We are both eaten up with anger about the loss of Charli, we both have an empty feeling of grief which feels like it will never end and a sense of living in constant shock. Our pain is indescribable. We were brought up as three very close sisters often mistaken for triplets and are now only two. At family Christmases, weddings and anniversaries we lay a place for Charli at the table. Seeing it empty makes every happy occasion sad. We spend Charli’s birthday at her grave. Time isn’t healing. We hurt just as much as we did in those first few weeks after Charli’s death. Our bereavement left us unable to function. Yet you married a woman you’d got pregnant within a month of the tragedy. We are stuck in an emotional fog because when you fled the court case, you stole our chance of closure and left us with unanswered questions.  You might expect us to lash out with threats or name-calling. But our family has too much dignity and decency. We know you don’t have a shred of either – because if you had a tiny speck of a conscience you’d have turned up at the Old Bailey to finally answer questions about the night you killed our sister. Instead, showing complete lack of respect for us and the legal system, you ran away. Your barrister excused your absence as cowardice. It’s also extreme arrogance and despicable selfishness. We wanted to hear what really happened that night you took Charli out on the Thames in a speedboat bought on Gumtree to “pull women”, as you smirkingly told police. Now we might never know. Why did you pester Charli for a date, tracking her down on Facebook after she blocked you on a dating site? When you knew of the dangerous debris in the Thames, why did you drive the boat at more than twice the speed limit in the dark?  Why take such risks while so drunk you didn’t know Charli’s name, or your own next of kin, when you were in the ambulance? We believe Charli would have survived if she had worn a life jacket. Why on earth didn’t you offer her one when you had two on board? So many questions. But our main one is: do you have any remorse? In the oppressively dark grief we searched for something good to come from Charli’s death. That has to be our petition to clarify and tighten laws covering dangerous driving and drinking while in control of a private boat. We won’t stop until we have at least 10,000 signatures so the Government will consider amending the very loose laws. Hopefully new rules will save lives and will one day be known as ‘Charli’s Law’.

title: heres pedestrianising parliament square really
story: NewsopinionHere's why pedestrianising Parliament Square is a really terrible ideaIt'll only send the terrorists to TescoShare&nbspByFleet Street FoxColumnist13:44, 15 AUG 2018Updated14:12, 15 AUG 2018NewsopinionGet politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailApart from the individual horror of being mown down by a speeding vehicle, yesterday's terror attack on Parliament was mostly harmless. No-one died. The terrorist was caught alive. There is no martyr, and if the worst they can do is smack their heads against a reinforced anti-terrorist barrier next to the most heavily-guarded building in Britain then, frankly, there's not a lot to lose sleep over.  Except there is, because as with every terror attack the hardest questions that must be asked are not, while official knees jerk to protect themselves.  Attacks on Parliament bring home to MPs that they are targets for those who take exception to their views, their politics or their existence. It's natural that after the second car-based attempt at mass murder on their place of work in 17 months, they would start to think that cars might be the problem. Only we don't say men are the problem, even though every single terror attack carried out on our shores of late has been conducted by people with testicles. The Islamists who have attacked us may have been Muslims, people of colour, slightly-thick zealots, and one-time petty criminals, but we have not and will not outlaw all such people for the crimes of a few. Boris Johnson would be stuffed, for a start. Yet some say it's time to pedestrianise Parliament Square. Because terrorists are never on foot, are they?   Terrorists have never been in cars, then got out of them to kill someone, have they?    Terrorists have never targeted places where all their potential victims are walking or sitting down, have they?   Terrorists are always the driver, aren't they?  Terror attacks often lead to changes, many of them useful. When the IRA bombed the Grand Hotel in Brighton it led to stringent security measures for party political conferences. After 6 were killed and 50 injured at the Westminster Bridge terror attack, Theresa May promised another &pound50m for counter-terrorism, having earlier been criticised for cuts.  And let's not be too architecturally-conservative about Parliament Square. It was laid out only in 1868, around the same time as the Victorians rebuilt the Houses of Parliament. It is a space owned by the Greater London Authority, which has the power to make bylaws for it, and has used this power in recent years to repeatedly curb the right to protest.  While there is a right to assembly on any public highway, on the roads around Parliament you must ask for police permission. So, on the face of it, pedestrianising the area - putting even the roads under local authority control, banning cars which happens anyway for approved protests, and keeping weapons-on-wheels away from the seat of our democracy - may seem like a sound idea. But it isn't.  Manchester Arena is not a public space, is privately-owned, and keeps its concert-goers away from vehicles. Salman Abedi still managed to blow himself and 22 others to pieces, killing and injuring huge numbers of children.   Abedi used a backpack and a suitcase. Parliament Square attracts millions of tourists a year, most of them with backpacks and suitcases.  Perhaps police and politicians would like bollards at the entrance to the square to include x-ray scanners, to catch those carrying bombs or knives in their backpacks?  In which case, we can look forward to everyone with a penknife or nail scissors being stopped, liquids being bagged and belts and shoes removed at the entrance to the square, just as they already are when you attempt to enter Parliament itself. And anyone who wishes to stage a protest or go to the TV studios at Millbank to criticise the government, will not only have to seek formal approval but be questioned as to their purpose on the way in and the way out. At this uncomfortably-authoritarian juncture, it might be wise to remind ourselves of the few times in recent history that Parliamentarians have actually been attacked.  Jo Cox MP was shot and stabbed on the roadside in Birstall, West Yorkshire in 2016 while on her way to meet constituents.  Stephen Timms MP was stabbed twice at a constituency surgery in a library in Beckton, east London in 2010.  More recently, Conservative life peer David Prior was the victim of a pig blood-based graffiti attack in his own home by an angry ex-girlfriend. When a brick was thrown through Angela Eagle's office, Stella Creasy was threatened with rape and Jess Phillips given death threats, it happened either in their own constituencies or online. And who could forget when deputy Labour leader John Prescott was egged outside a theatre in Rhyl, north Wales, in 2001 when on his way to a political rally.  As yet, no Islamist has yet come within 10 yards of a Parliamentarian at Parliament. Those who have launched attacks outside have not got in, and it has become quite apparent that while cars are good at killing pedestrians, they are rubbish at getting past armed police officers, metal barriers and brick walls.  Of course a Parliamentarian could be outside on his bike, as others were yesterday, or walking over Westminster Bridge, or coming through the gate at the wrong time. So could any one of a thousand other humans, and it is not for the public's sake anyone has suggested banning vehicles.  It has been suggested purely to look like something is being done - even though that thing would not deter a single terrorist. We have yet to hear of an incident averted because a devoted Islamist saw a 'keep off the grass' sign. They are not known for being law-abiding, and it should be noted that this latest attack involved an illegal turn on the wrong side of the road, in clear contravention of the Highway Code.  You can say this for cars being used as weapons - they tend to at least keep the driver alive. And if you ask any counter-terrorism officer what he'd like most after a terror attack, he'd say someone to interrogate.  He might further point out that, in his ideal world, the terrorists come to him. They choose the most-guarded, secure and bristling-with-police-officers building in the country, and run at it one at a time, almost as though they were idiots.  Parliament is a place that can handle terror. Blocking it off to cars does not stop terrorists - it just moves them down the road, to Tesco or the Tower of London or Top Shop. And there isn't a person on the planet who can't see that an attack on soft targets is not only easier for even the most stupid of zealots to manage, but it'll kill an awful lot more people.   Pedestrianisation is the go-to solution for every politician from the local town hall to Downing Street. Banning cars is the only way they can think of to boost local cafes, cut pollution and, now, protect democracy. Never mind that business rates, car manufacturers and sanity might all have more to do with it.  The ability to drive, in cars, taxis or buses, and to walk or cycle unhindered, through Parliament Square does two important things. First, it means millions of us get to see the place close up. On visits, school trips, holidays, the daily commute and in tiny glimpses on our way to somewhere else, we are reminded it is there, and that it is ours. If it were pedestrianised it would be seen only by those who seek it out. And secondly, it tells the terrorists - these dense meat-sacks who could not in any other situation terrify a wet kitten - that we are unmoved. Our democracy has survived worse, and it will survive them.

title: philip hammond urged freeze business
story: NewsPhilip Hammond urged to freeze business rates as high streets face tax hike of around £200million next yearMore than 1.2 million businesses will be hit with a rates rise again in April, and the scale of the increase depends on what inflation stands at next monthShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGraham HiscottHead of Business22:47, 15 AUG 2018NewsThe Consumer Prices Index measure of inflation rose to 2.5% last month (Image: PA)Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChancellor Philip Hammond faces fresh calls to freeze business rates as it emerged already hammered high streets face a tax hike of around &pound200million next year. More than 1.2 million businesses will be hit with a rates rise again in April, and the scale of the increase depends on what inflation stands at next month. The Consumer Prices Index measure of inflation rose to 2.5% last month. If it stays at that, businesses in England would see a &pound758million surge in their rates bills next year, according to analysis by industry experts Altus Group. Of that, &pound194million would fall on firms in the retail sector.  Robert Hayton, head of UK Business Rates at Altus Group, called on the Chancellor to take action. He said: “With our high streets engulfed in crisis, and Brexit uncertainty hurting manufacturers and the services industries, the Chancellor should be bold in his autumn Budget later in the year through an unprecedented stimulus by freezing rate rises.” Soaring business rates have battered high street stores already struggling to compete with online giants.  In a victory for our High Street Fightback campaign, the &shyChancellor last week said he was considering an “Amazon tax” on online sales to help level the playing field. Mr Hammond also brought forward a switch from the Retail Prices Index to the lower CPI to calculate rates increases to April this year, saving firms &pound2.3billion over five years. The amount raked in from business rates has surged by &pound6billion in the last 10 years.

Trying to sound like just another long-suffering commuter is the political equivalent of waving your arms around in panic. What a pathetic way to run a railway. This right-wing Tory has an obsession with privatisation but the real way to restore the network is to run it as a key public service, owned and operated by Great Britain. title: ron stallworth explains how became
story: NewsHow Ron Stallworth became the first black member of the KKK - and even became head of his local branchAhead of the release of Spike Lee film BlacKkKlansman, the undercover cop tells how he spent a year infiltrating the Ku Klux KlanShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByOliver Milne21:15, 15 AUG 2018Updated08:11, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTo his fellows in the Colorado Springs branch of the KKK , Ron Stallworth was in many ways the perfect Klansman. Always on time, well organised and, based on all the conversations the Ku Klux Klan’s members had with him, a powerful advocate for their hateful racist politics. What they didn’t know was that Ron was a black police officer. In 1979, Officer Stallworth, then 29, spent a year infiltrating the KKK and exposing their links with the police, military and organised crime. His audacious scheme, which started when he saw an advert in his local paper asking for potential KKK members, has inspired what some critics have called “the most important film of the year”, BlacKkKlansman. But in many ways, the truth is even stranger than Spike Lee’s movie makes it out to be. Working as an intelligence officer for the Colorado Springs Police Department, Ron was the only black officer on the force. So he took the rising tide of racist violence very seriously. And when he answered that advert, picking up the phone to talk to local KKK organiser Ken O’Dell, Ron knew he was risking more than embarrassment if they found out who he was.  America was gripped by far-right terrorism in the 1970s. In 1971, KKK members used dynamite to blow up ten buses which were to be used to desegregate schools in Pontiac, Michigan. In the months when Ron was planning his scheme, five communist protestors demonstrating in a Death To The Klan march were killed by the KKK and the American Nazi Party in the Greensboro massacre in North Carolina. In 1980, four black women were shot in Chattanooga, Tennessee, after a KKK rally. Just six months, later Michael Donald, age 20, was lynched in Alabama, his body found hanging from a tree. With this kind of bigoted violence going on, it’s fair to say that Ron knew the kind of character he was supposed to be playing when trying to ingratiate himself with the KKK’s O’Dell. Ron said: “I eventually spoke with him over the phone responding to that ad, and he explained to me that he was starting a Klan chapter in Colorado Springs and was looking for new people. “So I told him that I was a white man, that I hated blacks, Jews, Mexicans, Asians. That I thought the white man had not gotten a fair deal in this country. “[That] I was really upset because my sister had dated a n***** and it offended me that his black hands had touched her white body. And, as a result, I wanted to join the group and do what I could to put a stop to all of this nonsense.”  That was all it took – Ron, who now lives in El Paso, Texas, with his wife, was in. But very quickly he knew he was going to get caught if he couldn’t solve a major problem. How could he, a black man, walk into the public meetings of a large and violent racist organisation dedicated to seeing him back in chains? He was fine dealing with them over the phone, but he knew that when it came to having face-to-face meet-ups, he couldn’t go himself. So he drafted in his friend, Chuck, who worked in the drug squad, to be Ron Stallworth in person. It was also at this point that Ron realised he had – perhaps shortsightedly – signed his own name on his first letter to the KKK. However, it wasn’t just the practical problems holding up Ron’s investigation. Senior officers took a while to be convinced of its merits. “They felt like they couldn’t lose investigators to a bunch of nonsense like ‘men running around in sheets’,” said Ron. But with no signs of America’s racial violence subsiding, senior officers eventually agreed. Ron arranged to meet O’Dell, who was a serving soldier, at a bar near Fort Carson military base. He sent Chuck in wearing a wire, and guided him through the tricky conversations. “That’s how we conducted this investigation over the next eight or nine months or so,” Ron said. “I did most of the talking on the phone with these individuals, and when it came time for physical contact, the face-to-face meeting, I would send the white officer in posing as me.”  After months of phone calls and secret meetings, the infiltration was going so well that, incredibly, O’Dell recommended that Ron be made the head of the Colorado Springs branch of the KKK. He was put in touch with the hate group’s leader, David Duke. At one point – clearly confident that his plan hadn’t been rumbled – he even asked the KKK’s leader about the threat of infiltration. Ron explained: “I said, aren’t you afraid of an undercover police officer infiltrating your organisation or maybe a black man calling you up and pretending to be white?” “He said no, he wasn’t fearful of that at all, because he could always tell when he was talking to a black person.” Pushing his luck, Ron asked how Duke knew that he wasn’t black. “He said, you don’t talk like a black man. You talk like a very smart, intellectual white man. I can tell by the way you pronounce certain words.” Then, in an incident that seems more like far-fetched movie plot than real life, Ron – in his role as a serving police officer, rather than an undercover agent – met Duke in person. He was tasked with protecting the so-called Grand Wizard while he delivered a racist rant in public. He said: “I went and introduced myself to David Duke without giving him a name and told him I would do everything I could to protect him, even though I didn’t agree with him. We shook hands and I became his bodyguard.” Ron’s investigation in many ways highlighted his worst-possible fears. He found Klansmen in all walks of life, from local shop owners to school teachers and his neighbours.

title: amazon accused being complicit chargeback
story: NewsAmazon accused of allowing cheating customers to unfairly get refunds from online sellersSeller says unfair chargebacks mean buyers "get goods, file chargeback, get money back, keep goods"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew Penman17:00, 15 AUG 2018Updated08:14, 16 AUG 2018NewsScammed: Amazon retailer Steven Williams (Image: Sam Bagnall)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore trouble for Amazon, the tax-shy online retailer that's facing a string of controversies. This week watchdogs banned it from claiming that it can guarantee next-day delivery for customers using its Amazon Prime service. The Advertising Standards Authority ruled the claim misleading because “a significant proportion of Prime labelled items were not available for delivery by the subsequent day”. Amazon has also faced a storm over complaints that it's not paying its fair share of tax. Earlier this month the Mirror revealed that it paid just &pound4.6million last year despite UK sales soaring by a quarter to &pound8.8billion. British retailers with similar UK sales paid up to 20 times as much tax. Now one business seller using the service is claiming that Amazon allows cheating customers to unfairly get chargebacks. SaveMyLight sells lighting components and claims that Amazon has a policy of refunding buyers “at the drop of a hat to keep them happy”. The Midlands-based retailer says its customers have been refunded even when they don't return goods, or return goods that have clearly been damaged while in use, and some have even got refunds after returning goods that SaveMyLight does not sell. “The chargeback procedure on Amazon is in chaos and being continually abused with more and more buyers exploiting this now openly known loophole - buy goods, file chargeback, get money back, keep goods,” says sales manager Steven Williams. “Amazon are complicit in this by not ensuring goods are returned as per the Consumer Rights Act and instead wish to keep their buyers happy by simply removing funds from our seller account. “There are many other Amazon sellers affected and for us this has been going on for years.” He says that the problem is made worse by the difficulty in communicating with Amazon, with emails being unanswered. “If you telephone Amazon Support the call is answered by a Philippines operator who cannot assist,” he complains.

title: american dublin honeymoon facing three
story: NewsAmerican on Dublin honeymoon facing three attempted murder charges after pub brawlNicholas Keith Warner charged with attempting to murder three men, two of them aged in their 30s and one aged in his 60sShare&nbspByGeorge JacksonKelly-Ann Mills20:55, 15 AUG 2018Updated21:25, 15 AUG 2018NewsAmerican Nicholas Keith Warner is charged with three counts of attempted murderGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA recently married man, celebrating his honeymoon with his wife in Dublin, has appeared in court facing attempted murder charges. Nicholas Keith Warner, who arrived in Ireland last week, appeared at Limavady Magistrate’s Court charged with attempting to murder three men, two of them aged in their 30s and one aged in his 60s.  The three men each sustained stabbing injuries in an incident outside a bar at Main Street in the Co Antrim village of Ballycarry last Saturday night.  Warner, an electrical engineer from Morrow Lane in Summerville, South Carolina, denies attempting to murder the three men and he also denies assaulting a fourth man. The defendant further denies causing an affray but he admits possessing a knife.  The defendant, who sustained a broken leg in the incident, was helped by two police officers as he walked on crutches from a cell van on Main Street, Limavady, into the courthouse for his remand appearance. His wife Kaylee, a nurse also from South Carolina, sat behind her husband as he sat in the dock during the hearing. When asked by the court clerk if he understood the charges, the defendant replied “yes mam”. A detective constable told Deputy District Judge Ted Magill that he believed he could connect the defendant to the charges and he said alcohol was an issue in the case. Defence solicitor David Jones told the court that bail conditions proposed by the police and by the Public Prosecution Service were acceptable to the defendant.  “He accepts he was the individual who caused the injuries. From the moment of his arrest prior to his interviews he accepted he possessed the knife to defend himself”, Mr Jones said. “This case will come down to the argument of reasonable force or otherwise and because he is a US citizen I would request that if possible the case could be fast tracked. It is regrettable in that he is here on his honeymoon and his employment as an electrical engineer is now is jeopardy”, Mr Jones added. The defendant was released on his own bail of &pound1,000 to appear at Ballymena Magistrate’s Court on September 6.

title: best worst schools england wales
story: NewsBest and worst schools in England and Wales revealed - is your child's on the list?The Real Schools Guide 2018 utilises a range of date from attendance to student progress in order to rank state-funded secondariesShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByClaire MillerElaine McCahill10:50, 15 AUG 2018Updated11:24, 15 AUG 2018NewsThe best and worst state-funded secondary schools in England and Wales have been revealed (Image: iStockphoto)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe best and worst state-funded secondary schools in England and Wales have been revealed. Using information compiled by 's data department, we can reveal the best and worst performing schools.  Wembley High Technology College in Brent, London is the top school in England, while Cockshut Hill Technology College, Birmingham, has ranked last.   In Wales, Bishop Of Llandaff Church In Wales High School in Cardiff tops the rankings.  This is the sixth edition of the Real Schools Guide which is the most comprehensive guide ever on state-funded secondaries. The unique rating system uses 51 different measures, put together from the latest publicly-available data and broken into four categories – attainment, teaching, attendance, and outcomes. While national league tables may only examine GCSE results, the Real Schools Guide looks at schools which help all students to make progress, even if they only get slightly better than average exam scores overall.   See below to search for your school   Even those that include the new Progress 8 measure may overlook schools helping all pupils do well. The ranking system aims to give parents a better idea of which schools will help their child prosper, no matter what their background may be. The guide shows interesting trends with 80 per cent of the top 20 schools in England based in London and the South East.  What do you think of your school's performance? Email webnews@mirror   Four our of the top five schools in England are based in London. Just four of the schools are from the north and midlands with two form Lancashire, and one each from Liverpool and Reading. As well as this, girls-only secondaries make up half of the top performing schools in England's top 20.    In Wales' top 20, a quarter of the top schools are based in Cardiff while 25 per cent of the worst secondaries are in Flintshire. The top two worst performing schools in Wales, Glyn Derw High School and Michaelston Community College, both in Cardiff, were closed last summer to make way for the new Cardiff West Community High School. Other factors are also included in the data such as whether all pupils are making progress, attendance rates, the ratio of teachers to pupils, school finances, and whether students go on to further education or jobs. Attainment is worth 30 per cent of the total score. This is based on pupils’ Attainment 8, EBacc and GCSE performance in 2017.   Whether a school is getting top marks and if its GCSE results are improving year-on-year is also measured. Progress is worth 40 per cent of the score and is based on how well all as well as different types of pupil do in comparison to expectations and how well the school does at closing the gender gap. It also looks at how big the pupil/teacher ratio is in comparison to the national average, as well as teachers’ average salaries. The attendance score is based on absence rates, looking at both overall levels of sessions missed as well as unauthorised and persistent absence at the school. It is worth 15 per cent of the total score. Outcomes is also worth 15 per cent, and is based on what proportion of pupils continue with education, employment or training after Year 11, and what proportion leave employment, education or training within three months - in comparison to the national average.  Schools that had no Year 11 pupils taking Attainment 8 qualifying subjects in 2017 are not rated.  Speaking about Wembley High Technology College topping the list, Cllr Amer Agha, Brent Council’s Cabinet Member for Schools, Employment and Skills, said:     “Our aim is to ensure that every child in Brent has the best start in life possible, and so having one of our schools recognised as the best in the country, is hugely satisfying and testament to the hard work that’s been put in by everyone at the school.        “Coming a month after the council’s best-ever Ofsted rating and a few months after a Brent teacher won the Global Teacher Prize, this is another great day for Brent’s young people and I offer my sincere thanks and congratulations to all those involved.” The unique rating system uses 50 different measures, put together from the latest publicly-available data and broken into four categories - attainment, progress, attendance, and outcomes. National league tables may only look at overall GCSE results, as well as newer measures. Attainment This is worth 30 per cent of the total score. It is based on pupils' average grade attainment score, including what the average scores for different groups of pupils were, as well as the proportions gaining the English Baccalaureate and those getting A* to C grades in GCSE subjects. It measures whether a school is getting top marks, and if it is managing to improve year-on-year. Progress This is worth 40 per cent of the score. It is based on how well different types of pupil do in terms of progressing. It also looks at things that may contribute to teaching outcomes, such as how big the pupil/teacher ratio is in comparison to the national average, as well as teachers' average salaries. Attendance This score is based on absence rates, looking at both overall levels of sessions missed as well as unauthorised and persistent absence at the school. It is worth 15 per cent of the total score. Outcomes This is also worth 15 per cent, and is based on what proportion of pupils continue with education after Year 11 or go on to training and work.

title: british tourist who moaned benidorm
story: NewsBritish tourist who moaned Benidorm holiday was ruined 'by too many Spanish people' slammed by localsFreda Jackson, 81, said she cried at the end of her two-week trip and that the hotel her and a friend stayed at was "full of Spanish holidaymakers"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary20:29, 15 AUG 2018Updated20:31, 15 AUG 2018NewsFreda had visited the Benidorm hotel with a friend before being alarmed by the number of Spanish guests (Image: Lancashire  / SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British tourist who moaned her Benidorm holiday was ruined 'by too many Spanish people' has been slammed by locals. Freda Jackson, 81, said she cried at the end of her two-week trip and that the hotel she stayed in was full of Spanish holidaymakers. The grandmother, from Blackburn, Lancashire, went on to complain that the Spanish guests at the Poseidon Playa hotel were rude and that the evening entertainment was all focused and catered for the Spanish. Now, locals have hit back at the pensioner, saying she needs to scrub up on her geography skills next time she plans to take a trip abroad.  After the story appeared on Spanish news site Marca , one reader said: We should remind the good lady that Benidorm is in Spain.  Another said: If she hates Spain so much...why is she coming. It seems it would be good to learn some geography.  Freda had booked her Benidorm holiday in April 2017 after claiming travel operator Thomas Cook had recommended the hotel. But despite her request for ground access flat, Freda and her 61-year-old friend were placed on a slope instead. Grandmother-of-six Freda and her friend paid a total of &pound1,133 for the holiday and have demanded a full refund or a free trip. Freda said: I have never complained about a holiday before - but this one was a disaster from start to finish. She added: My friend and I paid for it from our pensions and it was a struggle trying to fund it over 12 months and the holiday was totally ruined - I cried after. The hotel was full of Spanish holidaymakers and they really got on our nerves because they were just so rude.  One evening a Spanish guy nearly knocked me flying and he just walked off without even apologising. The entertainment in the hotel was all focused and catered for the Spanish - why can't the Spanish go somewhere else for their holidays? Freda claims her requests for specific flats in the hotel were ignored and the operator failed to inform them of a change to the flights. She added: We wanted to go somewhere on flat ground and not in the hills because we have mobility issues. To top it off once we got to reception they told us we had been put on the 14th floor, thankfully we were moved to the second floor, and that it was 42 steps down to the hotel's swimming pool. The pair travelled 1,500 miles from Manchester Airport to Alicante on May 10, after not being notified by Thomas Cook that the dates of their flights had changed. Freda, who has previously visited Greece, Turkey, Portugal and Tenerife, claims Thomas Cook 'mis-sold' and 'ruined' her dream holiday.

title: builder tears down brand new
story: NewsBuilder tears down brand new £250,000 house because it was mistakenly built on top of major water mainIt could only be the start of Paul Mager's trouble, as the local council says it received no prior approval for the demolition workShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKeane Duncan10:15, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A brand new house thought to be worth at least &pound250,000 is being torn down because it was put up on top of a major water main.  Developer Paul Mager said he didn't know the underground pipe was there until after the two-storey, detached house was already built. He decided to matters into my own hands and tear down the house in Tetney, Lincolnshire, amid a row with Anglian Water that he didn't think he would win.  But it could only be the start of his trouble, as the local council says it received no prior approval for the demolition work, Grimsby Live reports.   Bulldozers moved in to demolish the executive house on Wednesday morning, sparking bemusement from neighbours. Mr Mager said the construction work could have ruptured the main, which serves homes across Cleethorpes and Waltham, leading to a major disaster. The head of Mager Homes Limited said: The detached house that is as we speak coming down has been built on the main water main from the Tetney Blow Wells. So that detached house has been built on the main water main artery that runs into Waltham and Cleethorpes. So to cut a long story short, having tried to do a deal with Anglian Water, it became apparent that the best thing to do was to take it down and re-site it.  It's a bit more complicated than that. But I have had a major row with Anglian Water and it looks like I was going to lose so I took matters into my own hands. Built on top of a main taking water from Tetney Blow Wells nature reserve, the house has never been occupied. It was approved in 2016 by East Lindsey District Council as part of an application for seven properties on Humberston Road. Mr Mager said: In order to avert that puncture taking place, the quickest thing was to take it down in order to avoid any damage to Anglian Water property. That little corner will be flattened and we will resubmit a planning application to redevelop in a different way.

title: farmer puts 30ft wall hay
story: NewsFarmer puts 30ft-wall of hay outside neighbours' homes - but denies that he's a "bully"Residents have accused the farmer of "bullying" after the bales were heaped outside their homes in DerbyshireShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByArun Lal19:06, 15 AUG 2018NewsPeter Shaw, 55 and wife Helen, 50, are furious after the hay bales suddenly appeared (Image: SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA farmer has denied that he is a bully after 30ft-high stacks of hay were placed outside his wealthy neighbours' homes. The massive stack of hay has been piled up on trailers in a field adjacent to the back gardens of several &pound500,000 detached properties. Villagers believe they were put there deliberately after a planning application by farmer Richard Barton to run a waste processing site was rejected. But Mr Barton has defended the move, accusing neighbours of making a straw mountain out of a molehill. Among those affected was resident Peter Shaw, 55, who said the bales were stacked behind his house on Cole Road, Ockbrook, Derbyshire, last Thursday.  Mr Shaw and his wife Helen, 50, moved into the home in 2004, and say this is the first time they have encountered an issue with Mr Barton. Mr Shaw, who works in the motoring trade, says the bales are a potential fire risk and is urging Mr Barton, 44, to remove them. He said: The farmer won't speak to you, I have tried. He's just a bully. I truly believe it is just something we are going to have to live with now. I have contacted everyone and anyone that I possibly can and nothing seems to getting done about it.  It feels as though there is one rule for one person and another rule for others. It's an eye sore - I'm not sure they are even stored correctly. He's put 30 tons on a trailer. First, the lorries came and they were full of hay bales and he put them in place one by one. So we've got three in a row. More and more bales were put on top - there might be a row of seven or eight - I'm not entirely sure now. You can see it from the road, you can see it from the footbridge.  It's about ten meters from my home - if they were to fall then they would destroy my garden. I thought they were a fire risk but the fire brigade said to me they're not a fire risk. The farmer has been trying to put a planning application through now for the past eight years. He wants to create a site to process waste. The application has been rejected not just by ourselves but by the whole village. It just seems because my house backs onto his farm - that we have to bear the brunt of this. Another resident on the street said: The view from our back garden used to be open fields but now all you can see is a wall of hay.  I'm convinced this is some kind of protest against the village because the farmer didn't get the planning permission he wanted. It's a form of intimidation and is just simply being done out of spite. Speaking from his farm in Ockbrook, Derbys., where he lives with wife Samantha, 50, he said: It's got nothing to do with the planning application for a waste processing site. Where am I supposed to put my bales? They [the residents] are selfish - all they think about is themselves. All they want to see is green land but I don't even get that view and its my farm. I've got my property here, I can't put them [hay bales] on my drive because there's no space - I've got sheds in the way too. There's a dual carriageway on the other side I can't put them there. He added: They're making a straw mountain out of a molehill. I put them in the middle of the field and they complained about that and the council told me to move them. Now I've moved them they're complaining again. All they've done for the past few years is try and portray me as some horrible neighbour and horrible person. It's not their fields - I live literally next to the bales too. The fire brigade have come out and said it's not a fire risk. I don't know why they called me a bully - I'm not a bully. I've lived here my whole life - my mum and dad have lived here too - we've always farmed. I've never not farmed and they're telling the council I don't farm.

story: NewsFather who took Viagra fractured PENIS after child jumped on bed trying to wake him upAccording to the British Medical Journal, the man expected its effects to have worn off after sex, but instead it remained working until the following morningShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary19:22, 15 AUG 2018Updated20:13, 15 AUG 2018NewsThe man reported to hospital two days after suffering a painful tear (Image: E+)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father who took Viagra fractured his penis after his child 'fell over' his erection while jumping on him to wake him up. The 36-year-old, who has not been named, had taken Viagra the night before the accident.  According to the British Medical Journal , the man expected its effects to have worn off after sex, but resorted to 'vigorous masturbation' when it failed to do so.  The following morning, the Viagra was continuing to work, before his child jumped on the bed in an attempt to wake him, but 'mistakenly fell over his erect penis', according to King George’s Medical University.  The journal goes on to explain how the man, from India, developed 'sudden severe pain in his penis and lost tumescence' - the build up of blood. After two days in agonising pain, he reported himself to doctors who confirmed a tear in his corpora cavernosa - the tissue that stores blood during an erection. His penis was said to be deformed and swollen from the injury.

story: NewsGatwick passenger running late for LA flight made hoax bomb threat to delay planeJacob Meir Abdellak, 47, from Hackney, east London, who became abusive to Norgwegian airline staff when they would not let him board the plane has been jailedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter10:15, 16 AUG 2018Updated10:16, 16 AUG 2018NewsJacob Meir Abdellak has been jailed for 10 months (Image: Sussex police)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A librarian who made a hoax bomb threat to delay a Gatwick flight he was running late for has been jailed.   Jacob Meir Abdellak called police reporting a bomb on board the Norwegian flight from London Gatwick to Los Angeles just eight minutes before it was due to depart.  A full re-screening by security staff at the airport meant the flight was delayed by 90 minutes on May 11. Investigations by Gatwick Airport staff revealed that Abdellak, 47, was significantly late for his flight and he was denied boarding before becoming abusive to airline staff. He was told to return on another date to rearrange his flight.  Police soon discovered the phone call used to make the hoax threat was the same number linked to Abdellak's flight booking. He was charged with communicating false information regarding a noxious substance likely to create serious risk to human health, however he denied the offence throughout. Abdellak, a French national, admitted the telephone number was his, but claimed he had lost the SIM card a few days earlier and therefore the call could not have been made by him.  But at Lewes Crown Court yesterday, when the trial was due to begin, the librarian changed his mind and pleaded guilty. He was sentenced to 10 months’ imprisonment and required to pay a &pound140 victim surcharge. Gatwick Police Chief Inspector Marc Clothier said: “This was a quite ridiculous decision made by Abdellak, who fabricated an extremely serious allegation purely for his own benefit. He was running late for his flight and thought it would be a good idea to call in a hoax bomb, however this turned out to be the worst decision he could have made.

story: NewsGovernment worker 'bound and gagged to chair by sexist colleagues' LOSES bullying and harassment caseDeeAnn Fitzpatrick claimed a racist and misogynistic culture within her office drove her to contemplate suicideShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCharlie Gall06:41, 16 AUG 2018Updated07:30, 16 AUG 2018NewsDeeAnn Fitzpatrick says she was bound and gagged at work in 2010 (Image: BBC)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA government worker who claims she was tied to a chair and gagged by colleagues who bullied and harassed her has had her case thrown out. DeeAnn Fitzpatrick, 49, accused fellow fisheries workers of mocking and targeting her in a campaign of sexist harassment. The Canadian woman claimed a racist and misogynistic culture within the Marine Scotland office in Scrabster drove her to contemplate suicide. But an employment tribunal has rejected her claims despite a photo showing her gagged and taped to a chair appeared to back up her claims, the Daily Record reports. That evidence was time-barred.  In an earlier hearing in Aberdeen in June, Ms Fitzpatrick alleged she was taped to a chair and gagged by colleagues in 2010. The tribunal heard how she was bombarded with fake Valentine's Day and birthday cards she believed came from male colleagues A message in one called her an “old troll” and another warned her about trying to “climb the ladder of success”. Ms Fitzpatrick told the tribunal the harassment was so bad she considered taking her own life and contacted an assisted suicide clinic. She told the tribunal: “When I first started getting the cards, it made me feel awful. But as they continued, yes it’s affected my self-esteem. “It’s actually made me become a recluse - I stay at home, I have gone more into myself. With everything going on, I contacted Dignitas in Switzerland. I had enough.” Ms Fitzpatrick, who has worked for Marine Scotland since 2006, was struggling to grasp the tribunal’s verdict.  She said on Wednesday night: “It is difficult when you spend your entire career fighting racism, misogyny and bullies. “Then to make matters worse when you report the incidents, you are the one that is being targeted by an ongoing campaign by senior management because you exposed what they have worked very hard to hide.” The Scottish Government put up one witness, Judith MacKinnon, its head of people advice, who has over 25 years experience in human resources. MacKinnon took up the job last year but said those who dealt with Ms Fitzpatrick’s complaints were too scared to appear because of the intense media interest.  But she backed the decisions taken by junior staff who found insufficient evidence to back up Ms Fitzpatrick’s suspicions about the letters. However First Minister Nicola Sturgeon told MSPs she was “absolutely horrified” when shown the photo of Ms Fitzpatrick allegedly taped to a chair and gagged. She has ordered a top civil servant to conduct a full review into the circumstances and report to her personally. Ms Fitzpatrick’s sister-in-law Sherry said: “The Fitzpatrick family are hugely disappointed with the result of the tribunal.

story: NewsA-Level results day 2018: Emotional scenes as hundreds of thousands of students across the UK find out their gradesMore than half a million students in England, Wales and Northern Ireland are receiving their A-level results today in the wake of major exam reformsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlison KershawSophie Evans08:11, 16 AUG 2018Updated09:44, 16 AUG 2018NewsPhoebe Crane opens her A-Level results at Norwich School in Norwich today (Image: PA)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of thousands of teens are finding out their A-Level results today - as figures show fewer students have been accepted on to UK degree courses. More than half a million students across England, Wales and Northern Ireland are receiving their long-awaited grades in the wake of major exam reforms. And initial Ucas data shows 411,860 have taken up places on British degree courses so far this year - down one per cent on the same point last year. These students are both from the UK and overseas.  A breakdown shows 353,960 UK students have been accepted on to undergraduate courses, down 2 per cent on 2017. It follows a drop in applications to start degrees at British universities this autumn, fuelled by various factors including a fall in the country's 18-year-old population.   A Level results day 2018: All you need to know when you get your grades and what to do next  In England, there have been huge reforms to A-Level qualifications - with a move away from coursework and modular exams. Instead, sixth formers sit their exams at the end of two years of study. This year, around one in four entries were expected to be awarded the highest grades - with possible marks going up to an A*. And this morning, it emerged one teenage boy from South Yorkshire has achieved a clean sweep of five A* grades in the exams. Jack Parkinson, from Thorne, near Doncaster, is now set to fulfil a childhood dream of studying at Cambridge University after gaining the grades. He will read computer science after his top performance in mathematics, further mathematics, computer science, physics and the extended project qualification. The 18-year-old, who was encouraged by staff at Trinity Academy to apply for Cambridge, attended summer schools there and at Oxford.    He said: They gave me a taste of the way of life there and the people were really down to earth, which I was surprised by. While many students hoping to go to a university or college of their choice will get the grades they need today, others will inevitably be left disappointed. But The Grand Tour presenter Jeremy Clarkson told them not to worry. He tweeted: Don’t worry if your A level grades aren’t any good. I got a C and 2 Us. And I’m sitting here deciding which of my Range Rovers to use today. University leaders have suggested that there could be more people who are using Clearing this year to apply to university for the first time. Last year, 26.3% of A-levels scored an A or A*, national figures showed. The results are likely to be broadly similar again this year. They come in the wake of the massive exam reforms. There have been major reforms to A-Level qualifications in England - with a move away from coursework and modular exams.  Instead, sixth formers sit their exams at the end of two years of study. A Department for Education spokeswoman said: We reformed A-levels after universities told us they were failing to prepare students for higher education. Reducing the number of exams students have to sit will give them more time for study and to gain a deeper understanding of the courses they are studying, an essential skill for undergraduate study. We know exam season can be a time of heightened emotions for pupils wanting to do their best but while testing has always been an important part of education, it should never be at the expense of a young person's wellbeing. That's why the Government is investing &pound1.7 billion to promote, protect and improve young people's mental health. Last year, the first grades were awarded in the first 13 subjects to be reformed in England and, among these subjects alone, the proportion of entries scoring at least an A grade fell by 0.7 percentage points to 24.3%. A further 11 subjects have been reformed with the first grades awarded today. Education Secretary Damian Hinds said the redesign of A-levels would make them more appropriate, better (at) preparing young people for moving on to the next stage, including university. He told Today: Having exams at the end of the two years means that it is possible to consider the subject as a whole, to bring in all the different parts of it, to synthesise the different aspects of the subject in a way that is a little closer to undergraduate study. But Amanda Brown, deputy general secretary of the National Education Union, argued that A-level changes means that students are unable to fully demonstrate what they can do. Changing the assessment of A-levels so they focus on high-stakes exams taken at the end of two years of study does not allow students to properly demonstrate their ability and puts them under huge pressure, she said. The A grade pass mark required for the reformed OCR advanced Biology A-level is 54.8%, the figures on its website show. Those wanting an A in the reformed maths exam would need to get 65.6% of the answers right. Meanwhile, students who sat the English language A-level would be looking for 77% of the marks in order to secure an A. Coursework and other non-exam assessments are a better way for students to demonstrate their skills, are less of a memory test, and help lower attaining students and those with special educational needs and disabilities show their achievements. One expert suggested that the proportion of top grades could drop slightly, by less than a percentage point, due to changes to the exam system, and a major hike in the number of unconditional offers handed out by universities. Mitigating this are a number of factors, including processes put in place by England's exams regulator Ofqual to ensure that results are comparable and the first cohorts of students to take new courses are not disadvantaged, Professor Alan Smithers of the University of Buckingham said. For those looking for degree places through Clearing this summer, there are suggestions that they are likely to find it is a buyers' market. A Press Association survey shows that, as of yesterday, 26,350 undergraduate courses were showing up on the Ucas clearing website for students in England. Nine in 10 UK institutions have at least one course listed in Clearing, the survey found.  It also shows that three quarters of Russell Group universities, often considered among the best in the country, have at least one course in Clearing, with almost 4,500 courses listed in total. The numbers of courses listed change frequently as different courses are filled, or become available. At the same point last year, the day before results day, there were around 27,715 undergraduate courses in total listed on Clearing with potential availability for students in England. Professor Alex Neill, vice-president for education at the University of Southampton, said that, nationally, there may be fewer people in Clearing this year for a variety of reasons, including a decline in the population of school leavers. But he added that there could be more people in Clearing who have not applied to university through the main application scheme. As part of a further trend that's developed over the last few years, we do expect to see more students in Clearing who haven't previously applied to university so an increase in the number of people who are, in fact, using Clearing as their entry to university, he said.  We have evidence that prospective students are receiving advice not to make a decision or application 'early', in the Ucas cycle, but use Clearing as a time when they will still be able to get entry to a high quality university and a high quality course, keeping their options open rather than pinning themselves down early. Lindsay Neil, director of admissions at the University of Westminster, said: Traditionally, prospective students apply to universities, receive offers and choose their first and second choice. They then have a long wait for their results to see if they have been successful or not. If unsuccessful students would then use Clearing as a back-up option to find universities who have courses with vacancies. Now however, the demographics are changing. The number of 18-year-olds applying for university is at a low point creating a 'buyers' market'. The majority of universities now open at least some courses in Clearing and this gives students a big advantage.

title: prince charles might not become
story: NewsWhy Prince Charles might not become King Charles when he takes the throneThe Queen's former spokesman revealed that Prince Charles will inherit a host of royal titles when he becomes KingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNeil MurphyCourtney PochinAudience Writer02:59, 16 AUG 2018Updated03:13, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Charles may not become King Charles when he takes the throne, it has been revealed. The Prince of Wales may change his name when he becomes monarch, according to Queen's former spokesman Dickie Arbiter. The first-in-line to the throne may instead change his official title to one of his middle names - a royal tradition that dates back generations. “He might choose one of his other names Philip, Arthur or George”, Arbiter told HELLO! magazine. Monarchs often assume new titles when they they become King or Queen, including the Queen's father King George VI. George VI was baptised Albert Frederick Arthur George - after his great-grandfather Prince Albert - and was called Bertie by those closest to him. King Edward VII’s Christian name was also Albert.  King Edward VIII used his original name but used his final middle name David with close friends and family Arbiter also revealed that Charles will inherit a host of royal titles when he takes the throne, including Duke of Lancaster, Defender of the Faith, Supreme Governor of the Church of England, Head of the Commonwealth, and King of other Realms and Territories.  He told Hello Magazine : Charles will also be Lord of the Man (Isle of Man) and Duke of Normandy.  “But generally he'll only be known as King.  Wills and Kate may also change their titles when Charles becomes king. Currently known as the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, the happy couple, both 36, could also gain two other royal titles. According to royal expert Marlene Koenig, the pair might inherit Charles' titles once he takes the throne. Speaking to HELLO! Magazine Marlene explained that while William will always be HRH Duke of Cambridge, he may end up being styled as HRH The Duke of Cornwall and Cambridge.

title: princess diana secret second wedding
story: NewsPrincess Diana had a secret second wedding dress - and she didn't even know about itPrincess Diana's wedding dress is an iconic piece of fashion history, but she could have walked down the aisle wearing something else entirelyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer09:47, 16 AUG 2018NewsDiana could have worn a different dress down the aisle (Image: PA)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Before Harry and Meghan and William and Kate, there was the grand royal wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer.   The pair officially tied the knot on July 29 1981 at St Paul's Cathedral and the world watched the fairytale ceremony in awe.   Diana's look for her big day is one that has gone down in fashion history, with her large princess dress made of ivory silk taffeta inspiring brides across the planet.  But it's recently been revealed that the 20-year-old princess-to-be could have walked down the aisle in a very different outfit.   According to People , the designers of her wedding gown, David and Elizabeth Emanuel , had made a second wedding dress for Diana - and it was kept so heavily under wraps that even the bride didn't know it existed.  A lot of effort went in to keeping the dress out of the public eye before the big day, with the designers even going as far as to destroy their sketches straight after they'd been shown to Diana. But in case the design for the original were to be leaked, another dress was created as a back-up option. At the time we wanted to make absolutely sure that the dress was a surprise, said David.  We didn’t try it on Diana. We never even discussed it. We wanted to make sure that we had something there it was for our own peace of mind, really. So Diana never even saw the second dress which was made from the same fabric as the first and also featured ruffles around the neck. However there were a few big differences between the two. The secret dress was a lot less lavish than the original version, lacking the antique lace and 10,000 mother-of-pearl sequins as well as the 25-foot train.

title: teenage lottery winner callie rogers
story: NewsTeenage lottery winner Callie Rogers dragged around by two women 'like a rag doll' after boozy night outMarie Hinde and Jade Quayle both face jail after admitting assaulting Callie Rogers - who scooped £1.86m aged just 16Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter07:50, 16 AUG 2018NewsThe court heard that Callie Rogers told the taxidriver she was 'the girl that won the lottery' (Image: Callie Rogers/Instagram)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of the UK's youngest ever lottery winners was attacked by two women after a night out, a court heard. The pair, both dogsitters, now face jail for their attack on the 31-year-old, who scooped &pound1.8 million when she was just 16.  They dragged the mum around a living room “like a rag doll” and left her bloodied and needing hospital treatment, according to reports.  Callie recently admitted she has struggled with the fame her huge win brought her back in 2003 when she won the big prize. She revealed how she blew her jackpot on drugs, partying and boob jobs. Much of her fortune went on &pound18,000 for boob jobs, &pound250,000 on cocaine, another &pound300,000 on clothes and she gave away &pound500,000 to friends and family. Callie previously said: At 16 you're just a child, then suddenly overnight you've got to become an adult.  You don't have any understanding of money and the concept of what it brings, she continued.  There were people who came along who I did not know before and have not been in my life since. At the time, you just want everybody to like you. The money did bring problems with my family, and friends as well. It just became too much to cope with. On the night of the attack, in July last year, she was in a taxi heading to her then-boyfriend's.

title: uk weather forecast summer heatwave
story: NewsUK weather forecast heatwave: Summer to return with temperatures soaring above 30CCooler weather brought a welcome break from extreme heat that lasted weeks, but stifling temperatures are on the way backShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBrett Gibbons08:02, 16 AUG 2018Updated08:31, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA heatwave that baked Britain for weeks could be on its way back with temperatures that could soar past 30C before summer's end. Warm and humid conditions are expected in parts of the country after days of cloudy and rainy weather brought a welcome break from extreme heat. Temperatures peaked at 35.3C in Faversham, Kent on July 26 as summer heat records fell across the country. Hot weather is set to return to the UK in the coming days and it could carry on into September, according to forecasts.  Until then, parts of Britain will see some miserable weather. Parts of northwest England and Scotland are braced for heavy downpours with up to 30mm of rain expected in some locations before the end of this week. But the chance of pressure building next week could bring a return to more pleasant, settled weather.    However, there is still a risk of showers or longer spells of rain further north - despite the improving picture. Fresh breezes are possible while the rain continues but there will be some respite, with occasional brighter and drier intervals likely, especially as the weekend progresses. In the south and east more dry weather will bring mainly brighter, sometimes sunny, periods. This could create some warm and humid conditions especially when the sun shines.

title: deformed crocodile left half smile
story: NewsDeformed crocodile left with half a smile after losing battle with fellow reptileThe reptile got into the tussle two years ago which resulted in him fracturing his jaw - meaning he now has a rather unusual smileShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth15:30, 15 AUG 2018NewsThe deformed crocodile in Vandaloor Zoo in Chennai, India (Image: Caters News Agency)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA crocodile was left with a deformed smile after a fight with a fellow reptile. title: six year old girl secretly
story: NewsSix-year-old secretly orders over £200 worth of toys on mum's phone - and has no regrets about itA mum received quite the shock when an Amazon delivery driver turned up at her house with over £200 worth of toys she hadn't orderedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer11:50, 15 AUG 2018Updated11:54, 15 AUG 2018NewsSix-year-old Kaitlin has gone viral after ordering hundreds of pounds of toys online - without telling her mum (Image: Twitter/@R_tatas)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've all been there. We've let a friend or family member borrow our phone for a seemingly innocent task and ended up regretting that decision. Typically it ends up with something embarrassing being posted on our social media or a whole load of weird and wonderful photos being added to your camera roll. But for one woman in Arizona, handing over her phone resulted in a rather large sum of her money being spent, without her knowledge. And it turns out the person who scammed her, was none other than her six-year-old daughter Kaitlin.   The day before the incident, Kaitlin's mum had let the child order a Barbie doll off of her Amazon account as a special treat.  Later on, the young girl had asked to borrow the phone to check on the delivery status of the doll. Her mum, being a trusting person, was happy to oblige her daughter's request.  But it turns out Kaitlin had an ulterior motive for wanting to go on Amazon .   The six-year-old decided to treat herself to $300 (&pound236) worth of toys, video games and board games on the account, and it wasn't until the next day her family discovered what she had done. An Amazon delivery driver turned up at their home the next day and started unloading box after box from his van. The girl's mum was confused, and checked her account, seeing, much to her horror, pages and pages of orders.  Kaitlin's cousin, Ria Diyalou, shared a post about the incident on Twitter , which has now gone viral.     She said: My badass little cousin ordered $300 worth of toys w/o my aunt &amp uncle knowing. This is a picture of how everyone found out. The picture showed Kaitlin stood by the Amazon van as the parcels were dropped off, a look of pure smugness on her tiny face. Clearly she had no regrets about what she had done.  Ria told Buzzfeed News : She knew exactly what she was doing when she did it. I was so surprised that a six-year-old knew how to do one-click, next-day shipping.

title: teenager 19 caught cctv trying
story: NewsMan tries to throw 14-year-old girlfriend in front of oncoming train in horrifying CCTVLucas Gary Narkle dragged his girlfriend toward the oncoming train as she struggled to avoid being hurled onto tracksShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter08:59, 16 AUG 2018Updated09:15, 16 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager tried to throw his girlfriend, five years his junior, in front of a train in horrifying CCTV footage. Lucas Gary Narkle dragged his girlfriend toward the oncoming train as she struggled to avoid being hurled onto the tracks at Elizabeth South station in Adelaide in October last year. The shocking incident was caught on camera at the station. Narkle, 19, faced the South Australian District Court on Wednesday, after earlier pleading guilty to endangering the girl's life. She was just 14 years old at the time.  The court heard Narkle's girlfriend was holding on for dear life as she was being dragged by him. She wasn't to know that he was going to stop, a prosecutor said regarding the incident. Narkle was originally charged with attempted murder and at the time was armed with a baseball bat, although both sides agreed it was not used. The 19-year-old was taken into custody following the incident and spent more than three months in prison until he was granted bail by the Supreme Court in February. Judge Simon Stretton said on Wednesday he was unlikely to impose further jail time on Narkle.  I have to bear in mind that his actual actions here are brief, irresponsible and didn't cause any physical harm at all, he said. I think nothing is going to be served by imposing a further term of actual imprisonment but I am strongly inclined towards an extended community service work. Narkle arrived more than 30 minutes late for the hearing, blaming public transport issues for the delay, reports Australian media. “Shout out to my boys in Yatala (Labour Prison),” was his only comment to reporters outside court. Narkle will return to court for sentencing on Thursday.

title: 200k improvements to dundee parks set to be approved
story: Dundee councillors are to be asked next week to approve spending more than £200,000 on a range of environmental improvements.Work is to be carried out at Balgay totalling £137,500.Elaine Zwirlein, director of neighbourhood services, said: “Work here includes the redesign and landscape improvements to include stabilisation of walls and installation of an overspill car park.“There will also be improvements to steps and additional tree planting. Friends of Balgay have been consulted regarding this.”Another £50,000 is to be spent carrying out improvements to seven playgrounds throughout the city.Ms Zwirlein said: “Works mainly include resurfacing and installation of wood chips, along with enhancing some of the equipment.“A further £29,500 is to be spent renewing fencing at Downfield Park and building a new gate.”
